1.verse: "If the corpse of a slain man is found lying in the open on the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you to occupy, and it is not known who killed him,

2.verse: your elders and judges shall go out and measure the distances to the cities that are in the neighborhood of the corpse.

3.verse: When it is established which city is nearest the corpse, the elders of that city shall take a heifer that has never been put to work as a draft animal under a yoke,

4.verse: and bringing it down to a wadi with an everflowing stream at a place that has not been plowed or sown, they shall cut the heifer's throat there in the wadi.

5.verse: The priests, the descendants of Levi, shall also be present, for the LORD, your God, has chosen them to minister to him and to give blessings in his name, and every case of dispute or violence must be settled by their decision.

6.verse: Then all the elders of that city nearest the corpse shall wash their hands over the heifer whose throat was cut in the wadi,

7.verse: and shall declare, 'Our hands did not shed this blood, and our eyes did not see the deed.

8.verse: Absolve, O LORD, your people Israel, whom you have ransomed, and let not the guilt of shedding innocent blood remain in the midst of your people Israel.' Thus they shall be absolved from the guilt of bloodshed,

9.verse: and you shall purge from your midst the guilt of innocent blood, that you may prosper for doing what is right in the sight of the LORD.

10.verse: "When you go out to war against your enemies and the LORD, your God, delivers them into your hand, so that you take captives,

11.verse: if you see a comely woman among the captives and become so enamored of her that you wish to have her as wife,

12.verse: you may take her home to your house. But before she may live there, she must shave her head and pare her nails

13.verse: and lay aside her captive's garb. After she has mourned her father and mother for a full month, you may have relations with her, and you shall be her husband and she shall be your wife.

14.verse: However, if later on you lose your liking for her, you shall give her her freedom, if she wishes it; but you shall not sell her or enslave her, since she was married to you under compulsion.

15.verse: "If a man with two wives loves one and dislikes the other; and if both bear him sons, but the first-born is of her whom he dislikes:

16.verse: when he comes to bequeath his property to his sons he may not consider as his first-born the son of the wife he loves, in preference to his true first-born, the son of the wife whom he dislikes.

17.verse: On the contrary, he shall recognize as his first-born the son of her whom he dislikes, giving him a double share of whatever he happens to own, since he is the first fruits of his manhood, and to him belong the rights of the first-born.

18.verse: "If a man has a stubborn and unruly son who will not listen to his father or mother, and will not obey them even though they chastise him,

19.verse: his father and mother shall have him apprehended and brought out to the elders at the gate of his home city,

20.verse: where they shall say to those city elders, 'This son of ours is a stubborn and unruly fellow who will not listen to us; he is a glutton and a drunkard.'

21.verse: Then all his fellow citizens shall stone him to death. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst, and all Israel, on hearing of it, shall fear.

22.verse: "If a man guilty of a capital offense is put to death and his corpse hung on a tree,

23.verse: it shall not remain on the tree overnight. You shall bury it the same day; otherwise, since God's curse rests on him who hangs on a tree, you will defile the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you as an inheritance.

annotations.1: [1-9] This paragraph is best read immediately after Deut 19:21. The slain man may not necessarily have been murdered; he may have been killed by a wild beast. But the blood of the slain cries out to God from the soil where it was shed; cf Genesis 4:10. Therefore a religious ceremony of propitiation is here prescribed in order to avert God's anger on the community
annotations.2: [4] They shall cut the heifer's throat there in the wadi: its blood is to be carried away by the stream, signifying thereby the removal of the human blood from the soil. This is not a sacrifice but a symbolic action; the priests are present merely as official witnesses
annotations.3: [6] Wash their hands: a symbolic gesture in protestation of one's own innocence when human blood is unjustly shed; cf Matthew 27:24
annotations.4: [7] This blood: the blood of the slain man as symbolized by the heifer's blood
annotations.5: [12-13] Shave her head . . . : these symbolic actions are meant to signify the purification of the woman from her pagan defilement or perhaps the end of her period of mourning for her previous husband
annotations.6: [19] The gate: in the city walls. This open space served as the forum for the administration of justice. Cf Deut 22:15; 25:7; Ruth 4:1, 2, 11; Isaiah 29:21; Amos 5:10, 12, 15
annotations.7: [22] Hung on a tree: some understand, "impaled on a stake." In any case the hanging or impaling was not the means used to execute the criminal; he was first put to death by the ordinary means, stoning, and his corpse was then exposed on high as a salutary warning for others. Cf Joshua 8:29; 10:26; 1 Sam 31:10; 2 Sam 21:9
annotations.8: [23] God's curse rests on him who hangs on a tree: St. Paul quotes these words in Gal 3:13, where he applies them to the crucified Savior, who "redeemed us from the curse of the law, becoming a curse for us."

1.verse: When Moses had finished speaking these words to all Israel,

2.verse: he said to them, "I am now one hundred and twenty years old and am no longer able to move about freely; besides, the LORD has told me that I shall not cross this Jordan.

3.verse: It is the LORD, your God, who will cross before you; he will destroy these nations before you, that you may supplant them. (It is Joshua who will cross before you, as the LORD promised.)

4.verse: The LORD will deal with them just as he dealt with Sihon and Og, the kings of the Amorites whom he destroyed, and with their country.

5.verse: When, therefore, the LORD delivers them up to you, you must deal with them exactly as I have ordered you.

6.verse: Be brave and steadfast; have no fear or dread of them, for it is the LORD, your God, who marches with you; he will never fail you or forsake you."

7.verse: Then Moses summoned Joshua and in the presence of all Israel said to him, "Be brave and steadfast, for you must being this people into the land which the LORD swore to their fathers he would give them; you must put them in possession of their heritage.

8.verse: It is the LORD who marches before you; he will be with you and will never fail you or forsake you. So do not fear or be dismayed."

9.verse: When Moses had written down this law, he entrusted it to the levitical priests who carry the ark of the covenant of the LORD, and to all the elders of Israel,

10.verse: giving them this order: "On the feast of Booths, at the prescribed time in the year of relaxation which comes at the end of every seven-year period,

11.verse: when all Israel goes to appear before the LORD, your God, in the place which he chooses, you shall read this law aloud in the presence of all Israel.

12.verse: Assemble the people - men, women and children, as well as the aliens who live in your communities - that they may hear it and learn it, and so fear the LORD, your God, and carefully observe all the words of this law.

13.verse: Their children also, who do not know it yet, must hear it and learn it, that they too may fear the LORD, your God, as long as you live on the land which you will cross the Jordan to occupy."

14.verse: The LORD said to Moses, "The time is now approaching for you to die. Summon Joshua, and present yourselves at the meeting tent that I may give him his commission." So Moses and Joshua went and presented themselves at the meeting tent.

15.verse: And the LORD appeared at the tent in a column of cloud, which stood still at the entrance of the tent.

16.verse: The LORD said to Moses, "Soon you will be at rest with your fathers, and then this people will take to rendering wanton worship to the strange gods among whom they will live in the land they are about to enter. They will forsake me and break the covenant which I have made with them.

17.verse: At that time my anger will flare up against them; I will forsake them and hide my face from them, so that they will become a prey to be devoured, and many evils and troubles will befall them. At that time they will indeed say, 'Is it not because our God is not among us that these evils have befallen us?'

18.verse: Yet I will be hiding my face from them at that time only because of all the evil they have done in turning to other gods.

19.verse: Write out this song, then, for yourselves. Teach it to the Israelites and have them recite it, so that this song may be a witness for me against the Israelites.

20.verse: For when I have brought them into the land flowing with milk and honey which I promised on oath to their fathers, and they have eaten their fill and grown fat, if they turn to other gods and serve them, despising me and breaking my covenant;

21.verse: then, when many evils and troubles befall them, this song, which their descendants will not have forgotten to recite, will bear witness against them. For I know what they are inclined to do even at the present time, before I have brought them into the land which I promised on oath to their fathers."

22.verse: So Moses wrote this song that same day, and he taught it to the Israelites.

23.verse: Then the LORD commissioned Joshua, son of Nun, and said to him, "Be brave and steadfast, for it is you who must bring the Israelites into the land which I promised them on oath. I myself will be with you."

24.verse: When Moses had finished writing out on a scroll the words of the law in their entirety,

25.verse: he gave the Levites who carry the ark of the covenant of the LORD this order:

26.verse: "Take this scroll of the law and put it beside the ark of the covenant of the LORD, your God, that there it may be a witness against you.

27.verse: For I already know how rebellious and stiff-necked you will be. Why, even now, while I am alive among you, you have been rebels against the LORD! How much more, then, after I am dead!

28.verse: Therefore, assemble all your tribal elders and your officials before me, that I may speak these words for them to hear, and so may call heaven and earth to witness against them.

29.verse: For I know that after my death you are sure to become corrupt and to turn aside from the way along which I directed you, so that evil will befall you in some future age because you have done evil in the LORD'S sight, and provoked him by your deeds."

30.verse: Then Moses recited the words of this song from beginning to end, for the whole assembly of Israel to hear:

annotations.1: [10] The year of relaxation: cf Deut 15:1-3 and the note there
annotations.2: [11-13] Reading the law not only instructed the people but also consoled them by the assurance of the divine goodness
annotations.3: [14-15,23] Deut 31:23 is best read immediately after Deut 31:15; perhaps the original order was Deut 7,8,14,15,23.

1.verse: "When we did turn and proceed into the desert on the Red Sea road, as the LORD had commanded me, we circled around the highlands of Seir for a long time.

2.verse: Finally the LORD said to me,

3.verse: 'You have wandered round these highlands long enough; turn and go north.

4.verse: Give this order to the people: You are now about to pass through the territory of your kinsmen, the descendants of Esau, who live in Seir. Though they are afraid of you, be very careful

5.verse: not to come in conflict with them, for I will not give you so much as a foot of their land, since I have already given Esau possession of the highlands of Seir.

6.verse: You shall purchase from them with silver the food you eat and the well water you drink.

7.verse: The LORD, your God, has blessed you in all your undertakings; he has been concerned about your journey through this vast desert. It is now forty years that he has been with you, and you have never been in want.'

8.verse: "Then we left behind us the Arabah route, Elath, Ezion-geber, and Seir, where our kinsmen, the descendants of Esau, live; and we went on toward the desert of Moab.

9.verse: And the LORD said to me, 'Do not show hostility to the Moabites or engage them in battle, for I will not give you possession of any of their land, since I have given Ar to the descendants of Lot as their own.

10.verse: (Formerly the Emim lived there, a people strong and numerous and tall like the Anakim;

11.verse: like them they were considered Rephaim. It was the Moabites who called them Emim.

12.verse: In Seir, however, the former inhabitants were the Horites; the descendants of Esau dispossessed them, clearing them out of the way and taking their place, just as the Israelites have done in the land of their heritage which the LORD has given them.)

13.verse: Get ready, then, to cross the Wadi Zered.' So we crossed it.

14.verse: Thirty-eight years had elapsed between our departure from Kadesh-barnea and that crossing; in the meantime the whole generation of soldiers had perished from the camp, as the LORD had sworn they should.

15.verse: For it was the LORD'S hand that was against them, till he wiped them out of the camp completely.

16.verse: "When at length death had put an end to all the soldiers among the people,

17.verse: the LORD said to me,

18.verse: 'You are now about to leave Ar and the territory of Moab behind.

19.verse: As you come opposite the Ammonites, do not show hostility or come in conflict with them, for I will not give you possession of any land of the Ammonites, since I have given it to the descendants of Lot as their own.

20.verse: (This also was considered a country of the Rephaim from its former inhabitants, whom the Ammonites called Zamzummim,

21.verse: a people strong and numerous and tall like the Anakim. But these, too, the LORD cleared out of the way for the Ammonites, who ousted them and took their place.

22.verse: He had done the same for the descendants of Esau, who dwell in Seir, by clearing the Horites out of their way, so that the descendants of Esau have taken their place down to the present.

23.verse: So also the Caphtorim, migrating from Caphtor, cleared away the Avvim, who once dwelt in villages as far as Gaza, and took their place.)

24.verse: "'Advance now across the Wadi Arnon. I now deliver into your hands Sihon, the Amorite king of Heshbon, and his land. Begin the occupation; engage him in battle.

25.verse: This day I will begin to put a fear and dread of you into every nation under the heavens, so that at the mention of your name they will quake and tremble before you.'

26.verse: "So I sent messengers from the desert of Kedemoth to Sihon, king of Heshbon, with this offer of peace:

27.verse: 'Let me pass through your country by the highway; I will go along it without turning aside to the right or to the left.

28.verse: For the food I eat which you will supply, and for the water you give me to drink, you shall be paid in silver. Only let me march through,

29.verse: as the descendants of Esau who dwell in Seir and the Moabites who dwell in Ar have done, until I cross the Jordan into the land which the LORD, our God, is about to give us.'

30.verse: But Sihon, king of Heshbon, refused to let us pass through his land, because the LORD, your God, made him stubborn in mind and obstinate in heart that he might deliver him up to you, as indeed he has now done.

31.verse: "Then the LORD said to me, 'Now that I have already begun to hand over to you Sihon and his land, begin the actual occupation.'

32.verse: So Sihon and all his people advanced against us to join battle at Jahaz;

33.verse: but since the LORD, our God, had delivered him to us, we defeated him and his sons and all his people.

34.verse: At that time we seized all his cities and doomed them all, with their men, women and children; we left no survivor.

35.verse: Our only booty was the livestock and the loot of the captured cities.

36.verse: From Aroer on the edge of the Wadi Arnon and from the city in the wadi itself, as far as Gilead, no city was too well fortified for us to whom the LORD had delivered them up.

37.verse: However, in obedience to the command of the LORD, our God, you did not encroach upon any of the Ammonite land, neither the region bordering on the Wadi Jabbok, nor the cities of the highlands.

annotations.1: [23] The Caphtorim: members of one of the groups of sea peoples who invaded the coast of Egypt and the southern part of Palestine about 1200 B.C. Caphtor: the ancient name of the island of Crete. Cf Amos 9:7.
annotations.2: [34] Doomed: see notes on Numbers 18:14; 21:3.

1.verse: "These are the statutes and decrees which you must be careful to observe in the land which the LORD, the God of your fathers, has given you to occupy, as long as you live on its soil.

2.verse: Destroy without fail every place on the high mountains, on the hills, and under every leafy tree where the nations you are to dispossess worship their gods.

3.verse: Tear down their altars, smash their sacred pillars, destroy by fire their sacred poles, and shatter the idols of their gods, that you may stamp out the remembrance of them in any such place.

4.verse: "That is not how you are to worship the LORD, your God.

5.verse: Instead, you shall resort to the place which the LORD, your God, chooses out of all your tribes and designates as his dwelling

6.verse: and there you shall bring your holocausts and sacrifices, your tithes and personal contributions, your votive and freewill offerings, and the firstlings of your herds and flocks.

7.verse: There, too, before the LORD, your God, you and your families shall eat and make merry over all your undertakings, because the LORD, your God, has blessed you.

8.verse: You shall not do as we are now doing; here, everyone does what seems right to himself,

9.verse: since you have not yet reached your resting place, the heritage which the LORD, your God, will give you.

10.verse: But after you have crossed the Jordan and dwell in the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you as a heritage, when he has given you rest from all your enemies round about and you live there in security,

11.verse: then to the place which the LORD, your God, chooses as the dwelling place for his name you shall bring all the offerings I command you: your holocausts and sacrifices, your tithes and personal contributions, and every special offering you have vowed to the LORD.

12.verse: You shall make merry before the LORD, your God, with your sons and daughters, your male and female slaves, as well as with the Levite who belongs to your community but has no share of his own in your heritage.

13.verse: Take care not to offer up your holocausts in any place you fancy,

14.verse: but offer them up in the place which the LORD chooses from among your tribes; there you shall make whatever offerings I enjoin upon you.

15.verse: "However, in any of your communities you may slaughter and eat to your heart's desire as much meat as the LORD, your God, has blessed you with; and the unclean as well as the clean may eat it, as they do the gazelle or the deer.

16.verse: Only, you shall not partake of the blood, but must pour it out on the ground like water.

17.verse: Moreover, you shall not, in your own communities, partake of your tithe of grain or wine or oil, of the first-born of your herd or flock, of any offering you have vowed, of your freewill offerings, or of your personal contributions.

18.verse: These you must eat before the LORD, your God, in the place he chooses, along with your son and daughter, your male and female slave, and the Levite who belongs to your community; and there, before the LORD, you shall make merry over all your undertakings.

19.verse: Take care, also, that you do not neglect the Levite as long as you live in the land.

20.verse: "After the LORD, your God, has enlarged your territory, as he promised you, when you wish meat for food, you may eat it at will, to your heart's desire;

21.verse: and if the place which the LORD, your God, chooses for the abode of his name is too far, you may slaughter in the manner I have told you any of your herd or flock that the LORD has given you, and eat it to your heart's desire in your own community.

22.verse: You may eat it as you would the gazelle or the deer: the unclean and the clean eating it alike.

23.verse: But make sure that you do not partake of the blood; for blood is life, and you shall not consume this seat of life with the flesh.

24.verse: Do not partake of the blood, therefore, but pour it out on the ground like water.

25.verse: Abstain from it, that you and your children after you may prosper for doing what is right in the sight of the LORD.

26.verse: However, any sacred gifts or votive offerings that you may have, you shall bring with you to the place which the LORD chooses,

27.verse: and there you must offer both the flesh and the blood of your holocausts on the altar of the LORD, your God; of your other sacrifices the blood indeed must be poured out against the altar of the LORD, your God, but their flesh may be eaten.

28.verse: Be careful to heed all these commandments I enjoin on you, that you and your descendants may always prosper for doing what is good and right in the sight of the LORD, your God.

29.verse: "When the LORD, your God, removes the nations from your way as you advance to dispossess them, be on your guard! Otherwise, once they have been wiped out before you and you have replaced them and are settled in their land,

30.verse: you will be lured into following them. Do not inquire regarding their gods, 'How did these nations worship their gods? I, too, would do the same.'

31.verse: You shall not thus worship the LORD, your God, because they offered to their gods every abomination that the LORD detests, even burning their sons and daughters to their gods.

annotations.1: [20] Meat for food: as on special feasts. Meat was not eaten every day in Israel, even by the wealthy.

1.verse: "You shall not see your kinsman's ox or sheep driven astray without showing concern about it; see to it that it is returned to your kinsman.

2.verse: If this kinsman does not live near you, or you do not know who he may be, take it to your own place and keep it with you until he claims it; then give it back to him.

3.verse: You shall do the same with his ass, or his garment, or anything else which your kinsman loses and you happen to find; you may not be unconcerned about them.

4.verse: You shall not see your kinsman's ass or ox foundering on the road without showing concern about it; see to it that you help him lift it up.

5.verse: "A woman shall not wear an article proper to a man, nor shall a man put on a woman's dress; for anyone who does such things is an abomination to the LORD, your God.

6.verse: "If, while walking along, you chance upon a bird's nest with young birds or eggs in it, in any tree or on the ground, and the mother bird is sitting on them, you shall not take away the mother bird along with her brood;

7.verse: you shall let her go, although you may take her brood away. It is thus that you shall have prosperity and a long life.

8.verse: "When you build a new house, put a parapet around the roof; otherwise, if someone falls off, you will bring bloodguilt upon your house.

9.verse: "You shall not sow your vineyard with two different kinds of seed; if you do, its produce shall become forfeit, both the crop you have sown and the yield of the vineyard.

10.verse: You shall not plow with an ox and an ass harnessed together.

11.verse: You shall not wear cloth of two different kinds of thread, wool and linen, woven together.

12.verse: "You shall put twisted cords on the four corners of the cloak that you wrap around you.

13.verse: "If a man, after marrying a woman and having relations with her, comes to dislike her,

14.verse: and makes monstrous charges against her and defames her by saying, 'I married this woman, but when I first had relations with her I did not find her a virgin,'

15.verse: the father and mother of the girl shall take the evidence of her virginity and bring it to the elders at the city gate.

16.verse: There the father of the girl shall say to the elders, 'I gave my daughter to this man in marriage, but he has come to dislike her,

17.verse: and now brings monstrous charges against her, saying: I did not find your daughter a virgin. But here is the evidence of my daughter's virginity!' And they shall spread out the cloth before the elders of the city.

18.verse: Then these city elders shall take the man and chastise him,

19.verse: besides fining him one hundred silver shekels, which they shall give to the girl's father, because the man defamed a virgin in Israel. Moreover, she shall remain his wife, and he may not divorce her as long as he lives.

20.verse: "But if this charge is true, and evidence of the girl's virginity is not found,

21.verse: they shall bring the girl to the entrance of her father's house and there her townsmen shall stone her to death, because she committed a crime against Israel by her unchasteness in her father's house. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

22.verse: "If a man is discovered having relations with a woman who is married to another, both the man and the woman with whom he has had relations shall die. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

23.verse: "If within the city a man comes upon a maiden who is betrothed, and has relations with her,

24.verse: you shall bring them both out to the gate of the city and there stone them to death: the girl because she did not cry out for help though she was in the city, and the man because he violated his neighbor's wife. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

25.verse: "If, however, it is in the open fields that a man comes upon such a betrothed maiden, seizes her and has relations with her, the man alone shall die.

26.verse: You shall do nothing to the maiden, since she is not guilty of a capital offense. This case is like that of a man who rises up against his neighbor and murders him:

27.verse: it was in the open fields that he came upon her, and though the betrothed maiden may have cried out for help, there was no one to come to her aid.

28.verse: "If a man comes upon a maiden that is not betrothed, takes her and has relations with her, and their deed is discovered,

29.verse: the man who had relations with her shall pay the girl's father fifty silver shekels and take her as his wife, because he has deflowered her. Moreover, he may not divorce her as long as he lives.

annotations.1: [9] Become forfeit: to the sanctuary; cf Lev 19:19; Joshua 6:19
annotations.2: [12] Twisted cords: referred to as "tassels" on "violet cords" in Numbers 15:38. See note there
annotations.3: [15] The evidence of her virginity: the bridal garment or sheet stained with a little blood from the first nuptial relations
annotations.4: [18] Chastise him: flog him, as prescribed in Deut 25:1-3
annotations.5: [23] A maiden who is betrothed: a girl who is married but not yet brought to her husband's home and whose marriage is therefore still unconsummated.

1.verse: "These then are the commandments, the statutes and decrees which the LORD, your God, has ordered that you be taught to observe in the land into which you are crossing for conquest,

2.verse: so that you and your son and your grandson may fear the LORD, your God, and keep, throughout the days of your lives, all his statutes and commandments which I enjoin on you, and thus have long life.

3.verse: Hear then, Israel, and be careful to observe them, that you may grow and prosper the more, in keeping with the promise of the LORD, the God of your fathers, to give you a land flowing with milk and honey.

4.verse: "Hear, O Israel! The LORD is our God, the LORD alone!

5.verse: Therefore, you shall love the LORD, your God, with all your heart, and with all your soul, and with all your strength.

6.verse: Take to heart these words which I enjoin on you today.

7.verse: Drill them into your children. Speak of them at home and abroad, whether you are busy or at rest.

8.verse: Bind them at your wrist as a sign and let them be as a pendant on your forehead.

9.verse: Write them on the doorposts of your houses and on your gates.

10.verse: "When the LORD, your God, brings you into the land which he swore to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, that he would give you, a land with fine, large cities that you did not build,

11.verse: with houses full of goods of all sorts that you did not garner, with cisterns that you did not dig, with vineyards and olive groves that you did not plant; and when, therefore, you eat your fill,

12.verse: take care not to forget the LORD, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, that place of slavery.

13.verse: The LORD, your God, shall you fear; him shall you serve, and by his name shall you swear.

14.verse: You shall not follow other gods, such as those of the surrounding nations,

15.verse: lest the wrath of the LORD, your God, flare up against you and he destroy you from the face of the land; for the LORD, your God, who is in your midst, is a jealous God.

16.verse: "You shall not put the LORD, your God, to the test, as you did at Massah.

17.verse: But keep the commandments of the LORD, your God, and the ordinances and statutes he has enjoined on you.

18.verse: Do what is right and good in the sight of the LORD, that you may, according to his word, prosper, and may enter in and possess the good land which the LORD promised on oath to your fathers,

19.verse: thrusting all your enemies out of your way.

20.verse: "Later on, when your son asks you what these ordinances, statutes and decrees mean which the LORD, our God, has enjoined on you,

21.verse: you shall say to your son, 'We were once slaves of Pharaoh in Egypt, but the LORD brought us out of Egypt with his strong hand

22.verse: and wrought before our eyes signs and wonders, great and dire, against Egypt and against Pharaoh and his whole house.

23.verse: He brought us from there to lead us into the land he promised on oath to our fathers, and to give it to us.

24.verse: Therefore, the LORD commanded us to observe all these statutes in fear of the LORD, our God, that we may always have as prosperous and happy a life as we have today;

25.verse: and our justice before the LORD, our God, is to consist in carefully observing all these commandments he has enjoined on us.'

annotations.1: [4-5] This passage contains the basic principle of the whole Mosaic law, the keynote of the Book of Deuteronomy: since the Lord alone is God, we must love him with an undivided heart. Christ cited these words as "the greatest and the first commandment," embracing in itself the whole law of God ( Matthew 22:37, 38 and parallels)
annotations.2: [8] Bind them . . . as a sign: these injunctions were probably meant merely in a figurative sense; cf Exodus 13:9, 16. However, the later Jews understood them literally, and tied on their wrists and foreheads "phylacteries," boxes containing strips of parchment on which these words were inscribed; cf Matthew 23:5
annotations.3: [13] Him shall you serve: here, to "serve" God means especially to "worship" him; in this sense it is quoted by our Lord ( Matthew 4:10) as an argument against worshiping the devil.

1.verse: "Every command that I enjoin on you, you shall be careful to observe, neither adding to it nor subtracting from it.

2.verse: "If there arises among you a prophet or a dreamer who promises you a sign or wonder,

3.verse: urging you to follow other gods, whom you have not known, and to serve them: even though the sign or wonder he has foretold you comes to pass,

4.verse: pay no attention to the words of that prophet or that dreamer; for the LORD, your God, is testing you to learn whether you really love him with all your heart and with all your soul.

5.verse: The LORD, your God, shall you follow, and him shall you fear; his commandment shall you observe, and his voice shall you heed, serving him and holding fast to him alone.

6.verse: But that prophet or that dreamer shall be put to death, because, in order to lead you astray from the way which the LORD, your God, has directed you to take, he has preached apostasy from the LORD, your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt and ransomed you from that place of slavery. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

7.verse: "If your own full brother, or your son or daughter, or your beloved wife, or your intimate friend, entices you secretly to serve other gods, whom you and your fathers have not known,

8.verse: gods of any other nations, near at hand or far away, from one end of the earth to the other:

9.verse: do not yield to him or listen to him, nor look with pity upon him, to spare or shield him,

10.verse: but kill him. Your hand shall be the first raised to slay him; the rest of the people shall join in with you.

11.verse: You shall stone him to death, because he sought to lead you astray from the LORD, your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, that place of slavery.

12.verse: And all Israel, hearing of it, shall fear and never again do such evil as this in your midst.

13.verse: "If, in any of the cities which the LORD, your God, gives you to dwell in, you hear it said

14.verse: that certain scoundrels have sprung up among you and have led astray the inhabitants of their city to serve other gods whom you have not known,

15.verse: you must inquire carefully into the matter and investigate it thoroughly. If you find that it is true and an established fact that this abomination has been committed in your midst,

16.verse: you shall put the inhabitants of that city to the sword, dooming the city and all life that is in it, even its cattle, to the sword.

17.verse: Having heaped up all its spoils in the middle of its square, you shall burn the city with all its spoils as a whole burnt offering to the LORD, your God. Let it be a heap of ruins forever, never to be rebuilt.

18.verse: You shall not retain anything that is doomed, that the blazing wrath of the LORD may die down and he may show you mercy and in his mercy for you may multiply you as he promised your fathers on oath;

19.verse: because you have heeded the voice of the LORD, your God, keeping all his commandments which I enjoin on you today, doing what is right in his sight.

annotations.1: [2,4,6] Dreamer: a false prophet who pretended to have received revelations from God in his dreams; cf Jeremiah 23:25-32; Zechariah 10:2. But dreams could also be a channel of true prophecy ( Numbers 12:6; Joel 2:32[ 3:1]) and of genuine revelations ( Genesis 20:3, 6; 31:10, 24; 37:5, 9; Matthew 1:20; 2:12, 13, 19; etc.).

1.verse: "When a man, after marrying a woman and having relations with her, is later displeased with her because he finds in her something indecent, and therefore he writes out a bill of divorce and hands it to her, thus dismissing her from his house:

2.verse: if on leaving his house she goes and becomes the wife of another man,

3.verse: and the second husband, too, comes to dislike her and dismisses her from his house by handing her a written bill of divorce; or if this second man who has married her, dies;

4.verse: then her former husband, who dismissed her, may not again take her as his wife after she has become defiled. That would be an abomination before the LORD, and you shall not bring such guilt upon the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you as a heritage.

5.verse: "When a man is newly wed, he need not go out on a military expedition, nor shall any public duty be imposed on him. He shall be exempt for one year for the sake of his family, to bring joy to the wife he has married.

6.verse: "No one shall take a hand mill or even its upper stone as a pledge for debt, for he would be taking the debtor's sustenance as a pledge.

7.verse: "If any man is caught kidnaping a fellow Israelite in order to enslave him and sell him, the kidnaper shall be put to death. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

8.verse: "In an attack of leprosy you shall be careful to observe exactly and to carry out all the directions of the levitical priests. Take care to act in accordance with the instructions I have given them.

9.verse: Remember what the LORD, your God, did to Miriam on the journey after you left Egypt.

10.verse: "When you make a loan of any kind to your neighbor, you shall not enter his house to receive a pledge from him,

11.verse: but shall wait outside until the man to whom you are making the loan brings his pledge outside to you.

12.verse: If he is a poor man, you shall not sleep in the mantle he gives as a pledge,

13.verse: but shall return it to him at sunset that he himself may sleep in it. Then he will bless you, and it will be a good deed of yours before the LORD, your God.

14.verse: "You shall not defraud a poor and needy hired servant, whether he be one of your own countrymen or one of the aliens who live in your communities.

15.verse: You shall pay him each day's wages before sundown on the day itself, since he is poor and looks forward to them. Otherwise he will cry to the LORD against you, and you will be held guilty.

16.verse: "Fathers shall not be put to death for their children, nor children for their fathers; only for his own guilt shall a man be put to death.

17.verse: "You shall not violate the rights of the alien or of the orphan, nor take the clothing of a widow as a pledge.

18.verse: For, remember, you were once slaves in Egypt, and the LORD, your God, ransomed you from there; that is why I command you to observe this rule.

19.verse: "When you reap the harvest in your field and overlook a sheaf there, you shall not go back to get it; let it be for the alien, the orphan or the widow, that the LORD, your God, may bless you in all your undertakings.

20.verse: When you knock down the fruit of your olive trees, you shall not go over the branches a second time; let what remains be for the alien, the orphan and the widow.

21.verse: When you pick your grapes, you shall not go over the vineyard a second time; let what remains be for the alien, the orphan, and the widow.

22.verse: For remember that you were once slaves in Egypt; that is why I command you to observe this rule.

annotations.1: [1-4] This law is directly concerned only with forbidding divorced couples to remarry each other, and indirectly with checking hasty divorces, by demanding sufficient cause and certain legal formalities. Divorce itself is taken for granted and tolerated as an existing custom whose evils this law seeks to lessen. Cf Deut 22:19, 29; Malachi 2:14-16. Christ gave the authentic interpretation of this law: "Moses, by reason of the hardness of your heart, permitted you to put away your wives; but it was not so from the beginning" ( Matthew 19:8, 9)
annotations.2: [1] Something indecent: a rather indefinite phrase, meaning perhaps "immodest conduct." At the time of Christ the rabbis differed in opinion concerning the sufficient grounds for divorce; cf Matthew 19:3
annotations.3: [6] Since the Israelites ground their grain into flour only in sufficient quantity for their current need, to deprive a debtor of his hand mill was virtually equivalent to condemning him to starve to death
annotations.4: [10-11] The debtor had the right to select the pledge that the creditor demanded as a guarantee for his loan.

1.verse: These are the words which Moses spoke to all Israel beyond the Jordan ( in the desert, in the Arabah, opposite Suph, between Paran and Tophel, Laban, Hazeroth and Dizahab;

2.verse: it is a journey of eleven days from Horeb to Kadesh-barnea by way of the highlands of Seir).

3.verse: In the fortieth year, on the first day of the eleventh month, Moses spoke to the Israelites all the commands that the LORD had given him in their regard.

4.verse: After he had defeated Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon, and Og, king of Bashan, who lived in Ashtaroth and in Edrei,

5.verse: Moses began to explain the law in the land of Moab beyond the Jordan, as follows:

6.verse: "The LORD, our God, said to us at Horeb, 'You have stayed long enough at this mountain.

7.verse: Leave here and go to the hill country of the Amorites and to all the surrounding regions, the land of the Canaanites in the Arabah, the mountains, the foothills, the Negeb and the seacoast; to Lebanon, and as far as the Great River (the Euphrates).

8.verse: I have given that land over to you. Go now and occupy the land I swore to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob, I would give to them and to their descendants.'

9.verse: "At that time I said to you, 'Alone, I am unable to carry you.

10.verse: The LORD, your God, has so multiplied you that you are now as numerous as the stars in the sky.

11.verse: May the LORD, the God of your fathers, increase you a thousand times over, and bless you as he promised!

12.verse: But how can I alone bear the crushing burden that you are, along with your bickering?

13.verse: Choose wise, intelligent and experienced men from each of your tribes, that I may appoint them as your leaders.'

14.verse: You answered me, 'We agree to do as you have proposed.'

15.verse: So I took outstanding men of your tribes, wise and experienced, and made them your leaders as officials over thousands, over hundreds, over fifties and over tens, and other tribal officers.

16.verse: I charged your judges at that time, 'Listen to complaints among your kinsmen, and administer true justice to both parties even if one of them is an alien.

17.verse: In rendering judgment, do not consider who a person is; give ear to the lowly and to the great alike, fearing no man, for judgment is God's. Refer to me any case that is too hard for you and I will hear it.'

18.verse: Thereupon I gave you all the commands you were to fulfill.

19.verse: "Then, in obedience to the command of the LORD, our God, we set out from Horeb and journeyed through the whole desert, vast and fearful as you have seen, in the direction of the hill country of the Amorites. We had reached Kadesh-barnea

20.verse: when I said to you, 'You have come to the hill country of the Amorites, which the LORD, our God, is giving us.

21.verse: The LORD, your God, has given this land over to you. Go up and occupy it, as the LORD, the God of your fathers, commands you. Do not fear or lose heart.'

22.verse: Then all of you came up to me and said, 'Let us send men ahead to reconnoiter the land for us and report to us on the road we must follow and the cities we must take.'

23.verse: Agreeing with the proposal, I chose twelve men from your number, one from each tribe.

24.verse: They set out into the hill country as far as the Wadi Eshcol, and explored it.

25.verse: Then, taking along some of the fruit of the land, they brought it down to us and reported, 'The land which the LORD, our God, gives us is good.'

26.verse: "But you refused to go up, and after defying the command of the LORD, your God,

27.verse: you set to murmuring in your tents, 'Out of hatred for us the LORD has brought us up out of the land of Egypt, to deliver us into the hands of the Amorites and destroy us.

28.verse: What shall we meet with up there? Our kinsmen have made us fainthearted by reporting that the people are stronger and taller than we, and their cities are large and fortified to the sky; besides, they saw the Anakim there.'

29.verse: "But I said to you, 'Have no dread or fear of them.

30.verse: The LORD, your God, who goes before you, will himself fight for you, just as he took your part before your very eyes in Egypt,

31.verse: as well as in the desert, where you saw how the LORD, your God, carried you, as a man carries his child, all along your journey until you arrived at this place.'

32.verse: Despite this, you would not trust the LORD, your God,

33.verse: who journeys before you to find you a resting place - by day in the cloud, and by night in the fire, to show the way you must go.

34.verse: When the LORD heard your words, he was angry;

35.verse: and he swore, 'Not one man of this evil generation shall look upon the good land I swore to give to your fathers,

36.verse: except Caleb, son of Jephunneh; he shall see it. For to him and to his sons I will give the land he trod upon, because he has followed the LORD unreservedly.'

37.verse: "The LORD was angered against me also on your account, and said, 'Not even you shall enter there,

38.verse: but your aide Joshua, son of Nun, shall enter. Encourage him, for he is to give Israel its heritage.

39.verse: Your little ones, who you said would become booty, and your children, who as yet do not know good from bad - they shall enter; to them I will give it, and they shall occupy it.

40.verse: But as for yourselves: turn about and proceed into the desert on the Red Sea road.'

41.verse: "In reply you said to me, 'We have sinned against the LORD. We will go up ourselves and fight, just as the LORD, our God, commanded us.' And each of you girded on his weapons, making light of going up into the hill country.

42.verse: But the LORD said to me, 'Warn them: Do not go up and fight, lest you be beaten down before your enemies, for I will not be in your midst.'

43.verse: I gave you this warning but you would not listen. In defiance of the LORD'S command you arrogantly marched off into the hill country.

44.verse: Then the Amorites living there came out against you and, like bees, chased you, cutting you down in Seir as far as Hormah.

45.verse: On your return you wept before the LORD, but he did not listen to your cry or give ear to you.

46.verse: That is why you had to stay as long as you did at Kadesh.

annotations.1: [1] The local setting of all these discourses is in the land of Moab beyond the Jordan (cf Deut 1:5), also known as the plains of Moab ( Numbers 36:13)
annotations.2: [7] The Amorites and the Canaanites formed the principal part of the pre-Israelite population of Palestine. The foothills: the hills on the western slope of the Judean mountain range. The Arabah: the valley of the Jordan and the depression south of the Dead Sea. The Negeb: the arid land in southern Palestine
annotations.3: [9] Carry you: cf Deut 1:31
annotations.5: [36] Except Caleb: Joshua also was allowed to enter, but he is not referred to here because special mention is made of him in Deut 1:38 as the successor of Moses.

1.verse: "You shall not sacrifice to the LORD, your God, from the herd or from the flock an animal with any serious defect; that would be an abomination to the LORD, your God.

2.verse: "If there is found among you, in any one of the communities which the LORD, your God, gives you, a man or a woman who does evil in the sight of the LORD, your God, and transgresses his covenant,

3.verse: by serving other gods, or by worshiping the sun or the moon or any of the host of the sky, against my command;

4.verse: and if, on being informed of it, you find by careful investigation that it is true and an established fact that this abomination has been committed in Israel:

5.verse: you shall bring the man (or woman) who has done the evil deed out to your city gates and stone him to death.

6.verse: The testimony of two or three witnesses is required for putting a person to death; no one shall be put to death on the testimony of only one witness.

7.verse: At the execution, the witnesses are to be the first to raise their hands against him; afterward all the people are to join in. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

8.verse: "If in your own community there is a case at issue which proves too complicated for you to decide, in a matter of bloodshed or of civil rights or of personal injury, you shall then go up to the place which the LORD, your God, chooses,

9.verse: to the levitical priests or to the judge who is in office at that time. They shall study the case and then hand down to you their decision.

10.verse: According to this decision that they give you in the place which the LORD chooses, you shall act, being careful to do exactly as they direct.

11.verse: You shall carry out the directions they give you and the verdict they pronounce for you, without turning aside to the right or to the left from the decision they hand down to you.

12.verse: Any man who has the insolence to refuse to listen to the priest who officiates there in the ministry of the LORD, your God, or to the judge, shall die. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

13.verse: And all the people, on hearing of it, shall fear, and never again be so insolent.

14.verse: "When you have come into the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you, and have occupied it and settled in it, should you then decide to have a king over you like all the surrounding nations,

15.verse: you shall set that man over you as your king whom the LORD, your God, chooses. He whom you set over you as king must be your kinsman; a foreigner, who is no kin of yours, you may not set over you.

16.verse: But he shall not have a great number of horses; nor shall he make his people go back again to Egypt to acquire them, against the LORD'S warning that you must never go back that way again.

17.verse: Neither shall he have a great number of wives, lest his heart be estranged, nor shall he accumulate a vast amount of silver and gold.

18.verse: When he is enthroned in his kingdom, he shall have a copy of this law made from the scroll that is in the custody of the levitical priests.

19.verse: He shall keep it with him and read it all the days of his life that he may learn to fear the LORD, his God, and to heed and fulfill all the words of this law and these statutes.

20.verse: Let him not become estranged from his countrymen through pride, nor turn aside to the right or to the left from these commandments. Then he and his descendants will enjoy a long reign in Israel.

annotations.1: [5] Out to your city gates: outside the gates in an unclean place; cf Lev 24:14; Numbers 15:36; Acts 7:58; Hebrews 13:12
annotations.2: [12] The priest: the high priest; the judge: a layman. The former presided over the court in cases which directly concerned religion, the latter in cases of a more secular nature; cf 2 Chron 19:8-11
annotations.3: [16] Horses: chariotry for war. The LORD'S warning: the same warning is also referred to in Deut 28:68, although it is not mentioned explicitly elsewhere in the Pentateuch. We know from other sources that Egypt used to export war horses to Palestine. The danger envisioned here is that some king might make Israel a vassal of Egypt for the sake of such military aid.

1.verse: "When the LORD, your God, brings you into the land which you are to enter and occupy, and dislodges great nations before you - the Hittites, Girgashites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites: seven nations more numerous and powerful than you -

2.verse: and when the LORD, your God, delivers them up to you and you defeat them, you shall doom them. Make no covenant with them and show them no mercy.

3.verse: You shall not intermarry with them, neither giving your daughters to their sons nor taking their daughters for your sons.

4.verse: For they would turn your sons from following me to serving other gods, and then the wrath of the LORD would flare up against you and quickly destroy you.

5.verse: "But this is how you must deal with them: Tear down their altars, smash their sacred pillars, chop down their sacred poles, and destroy their idols by fire.

6.verse: For you are a people sacred to the LORD, your God; he has chosen you from all the nations on the face of the earth to be a people peculiarly his own.

7.verse: It was not because you are the largest of all nations that the LORD set his heart on you and chose you, for you are really the smallest of all nations.

8.verse: It was because the LORD loved you and because of his fidelity to the oath he had sworn to your fathers, that he brought you out with his strong hand from the place of slavery, and ransomed you from the hand of Pharaoh, king of Egypt.

9.verse: Understand, then, that the LORD, your God, is God indeed, the faithful God who keeps his merciful covenant down to the thousandth generation toward those who love him and keep his commandments,

10.verse: but who repays with destruction the person who hates him; he does not dally with such a one, but makes him personally pay for it.

11.verse: You shall therefore carefully observe the commandments, the statutes and the decrees which I enjoin on you today.

12.verse: "As your reward for heeding these decrees and observing them carefully, the LORD, your God, will keep with you the merciful covenant which he promised on oath to your fathers.

13.verse: He will love and bless and multiply you; he will bless the fruit of your womb and the produce of your soil, your grain and wine and oil, the issue of your herds and the young of your flocks, in the land which he swore to your fathers he would give you.

14.verse: You will be blessed above all peoples; no man or woman among you shall be childless nor shall your livestock be barren.

15.verse: The LORD will remove all sickness from you; he will not afflict you with any of the malignant diseases that you know from Egypt, but will leave them with all your enemies.

16.verse: "You shall consume all the nations which the LORD, your God, will deliver up to you. You are not to look on them with pity, lest you be ensnared into serving their gods.

17.verse: Perhaps you will say to yourselves, 'These nations are greater than we. How can we dispossess them?'

18.verse: But do not be afraid of them. Rather, call to mind what the LORD, your God, did to Pharaoh and to all Egypt:

19.verse: the great testings which your own eyes have seen, the signs and wonders, his strong hand and outstretched arm with which the LORD, your God, brought you out. The same also will he do to all the nations of whom you are now afraid.

20.verse: Moreover, the LORD, your God, will send hornets among them, until the survivors who have hidden from you are destroyed.

21.verse: Therefore, do not be terrified by them, for the LORD, your God, who is in your midst, is a great and awesome God.

22.verse: He will dislodge these nations before you little by little. You cannot exterminate them all at once, lest the wild beasts become too numerous for you.

23.verse: The LORD, your God, will deliver them up to you and will rout them utterly until they are annihilated.

24.verse: He will deliver their kings into your hand, that you may make their names perish from under the heavens. No man will be able to stand up against you, till you have put an end to them.

25.verse: The images of their gods you shall destroy by fire. Do not covet the silver or gold on them, nor take it for yourselves, lest you be ensnared by it; for it is an abomination to the LORD, your God.

26.verse: You shall not bring any abominable thing into your house, lest you be doomed with it; loathe and abhor it utterly as a thing that is doomed.

1.verse: Moses summoned all Israel and said to them, "You have seen all that the LORD did in the land of Egypt before your very eyes to Pharaoh and all his servants and to all his land;

2.verse: the great testings your own eyes have seen, and those great signs and wonders.

3.verse: But not even at the present day has the LORD yet given you a mind to understand, or eyes to see, or ears to hear.

4.verse: 'I led you for forty years in the desert. Your clothes did not fall from you in tatters nor your sandals from your feet;

5.verse: bread was not your food, nor wine or beer your drink. Thus you should know that I, the LORD, am your God.'

6.verse: When we came to this place, Sihon, king of Heshbon, and Og, king of Bashan, came out to engage us in battle, but we defeated them

7.verse: and took over their land, which we then gave as a heritage to the Reubenites, Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh.

8.verse: Keep the terms of this covenant, therefore, and fulfill them, that you may succeed in whatever you do.

9.verse: "You are all now standing before the LORD, your God - your chiefs and judges, your elders and officials, and all of the men of Israel,

10.verse: together with your wives and children and the aliens who live in your camp, down to those who hew wood and draw water for you -

11.verse: that you may enter into the covenant of the LORD, your God, which he concluded with you today under this sanction of a curse;

12.verse: so that he may now establish you as his people and he may be your God, as he promised you and as he swore to your fathers Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

13.verse: But it is not with you alone that I am making this covenant, under this sanction of a curse;

14.verse: it is just as much with those who are not here among us today as it is with those of us who are now here present before the LORD, our God.

15.verse: "You know in what surroundings we lived in the land of Egypt and what we passed by in the nations we traversed,

16.verse: and you saw the loathsome idols of wood and stone, of gold and silver, that they possess.

17.verse: Let there be, then, no man or woman, no clan or tribe among you, who would now turn away their hearts from the LORD, our God, to go and serve these pagan gods! Let there be no root that would bear such poison and wormwood among you.

18.verse: If any such person, upon hearing the words of this curse, should beguile himself into thinking that he can safely persist in his stubbornness of heart, as though to sweep away both the watered soil and the parched ground,

19.verse: the LORD will never consent to pardon him. Instead, the LORD'S wrath and jealousy will flare up against that man, and every curse mentioned in this book will alight on him. The LORD will blot out his name from under the heavens

20.verse: and will single him out from all the tribes of Israel for doom, in keeping with all the curses of the covenant inscribed in this book of the law.

21.verse: "Future generations, your own descendants who will rise up after you, as well as the foreigners who will come here from far-off lands, when they see the calamities of this land and the ills with which the LORD has smitten it -

22.verse: all its soil being nothing but sulphur and salt, a burnt-out waste, unsown and unfruitful, without a blade of grass, destroyed like Sodom and Gomorrah, Admah and Zeboiim, which the LORD overthrew in his furious wrath -

23.verse: they and all the nations will ask, 'Why has the LORD dealt thus with this land? Why this fierce outburst of wrath?'

24.verse: And the answer will be, 'Because they forsook the covenant which the LORD, the God of their fathers, had made with them when he brought them out of the land of Egypt,

25.verse: and they went and served other gods and adored them, gods whom they did not know and whom he had not let fall to their lot:

26.verse: that is why the LORD was angry with this land and brought on it all the imprecations listed in this book;

27.verse: in his furious wrath and tremendous anger the LORD uprooted them from their soil and cast them out into a strange land, where they are today.'

28.verse: (Both what is still hidden and what has already been revealed concern us and our descendants forever, that we may carry out all the words of this law.)

annotations.1: [3] Eyes to see . . . ears to hear: with inner, spiritual discernment. Cf Matthew 13:43
annotations.2: [11] Sanction of a curse: the present pact binds under penalty of the curses mentioned in this book. Cf Deut 29:20
annotations.3: [14] Not here among us: this includes their descendants
annotations.4: [18] To sweep away both the watered soil and the parched ground: apparently a proverb signifying that such an unfaithful Israelite will cause God to punish the good with the wicked, to root out the good plants growing in irrigated soil, together with the worthless plants growing in the dry ground
annotations.5: [28] What is still hidden: the events of the future. What has already been revealed: God's law and the punishments in store for those who break it. Leave the future to God; our business is to keep his law.

1.verse: "When men have a dispute and bring it to court, and a decision is handed down to them acquitting the innocent party and condemning the guilty party,

2.verse: if the latter deserves stripes, the judge shall have him lie down and in his presence receive the number of stripes his guilt deserves.

3.verse: Forty stripes may be given him, but no more; lest, if he were beaten with more stripes than these, your kinsman should be looked upon as disgraced because of the severity of the beating.

4.verse: "You shall not muzzle an ox when it is treading out grain.

5.verse: "When brothers live together and one of them dies without a son, the widow of the deceased shall not marry anyone outside the family; but her husband's brother shall go to her and perform the duty of a brother-in-law by marrying her.

6.verse: The first-born son she bears shall continue the line of the deceased brother, that his name may not be blotted out from Israel.

7.verse: If, however, a man does not care to marry his brother's wife, she shall go up to the elders at the gate and declare, 'My brother-in-law does not intend to perform his duty toward me and refuses to perpetuate his brother's name in Israel.'

8.verse: Thereupon the elders of his city shall summon him and admonish him. If he persists in saying, 'I am not willing to marry her,'

9.verse: his sister-in-law, in the presence of the elders, shall go up to him and strip his sandal from his foot and spit in his face, saying publicly, 'This is how one should be treated who will not build up his brother's family!'

10.verse: And his lineage shall be spoken of in Israel as 'the family of the man stripped of his sandal.'

11.verse: "When two men are fighting and the wife of one intervenes to save her husband from the blows of his opponent, if she stretches out her hand and seizes the latter by his private parts,

12.verse: you shall chop off her hand without pity.

13.verse: "You shall not keep two differing weights in your bag, one large and the other small;

14.verse: nor shall you keep two different measures in your house, one large and the other small.

15.verse: But use a true and just weight, and a true and just measure, that you may have a long life on the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you.

16.verse: Everyone who is dishonest in any of these matters is an abomination to the LORD, your God.

17.verse: "Bear in mind what Amalek did to you on the journey after you left Egypt,

18.verse: how without fear of any god he harassed you along the way, weak and weary as you were, and cut off at the rear all those who lagged behind.

19.verse: Therefore, when the LORD, your God, gives you rest from all your enemies round about in the land which he is giving you to occupy as your heritage, you shall blot out the memory of Amalek from under the heavens. Do not forget!

annotations.1: [3] Forty stripes: a relatively mild punishment in ancient times. Later Jewish practice limited the number to thirty-nine; cf 2 Cor 11:24
annotations.2: [4] St. Paul argues from this verse that a laborer has the right to live on the fruits of his labor; cf 1 Cor 9:9; 1 Tim 5:18
annotations.3: [5] When brothers live together: when relatives of the same clan, though married, hold their property in common. It was only in this case that the present law was to be observed, since one of its purposes was to keep the property of the deceased within the same clan. Such a marriage of a widow with her brother-in-law is known as a "levirate" marriage from the Latin word levir, meaning "a husband's brother.&quot
annotations.4: [9-10] The penalty decreed for a man who refuses to comply with this law of family loyalty is public disgrace (the widow is to spit in his face) and the curse of poverty; sandals were proverbially a man's cheapest possession (cf Amos 2:6; 8:6), and therefore "a man without sandals" was the poorest of the poor. Some commentators, however, connect this symbolic act with the ceremony mentioned in Ruth 4:7, 8
annotations.5: [17-19] This attack on Israel by Amalek is not mentioned elsewhere in the Old Testament, although it probably was connected with the battle mentioned in Exodus 17:8. A campaign against Amalek was carried out by Saul; cf 1 Sam 15.

1.verse: "When all these things which I have set before you, the blessings and the curses, are fulfilled in you, and from among whatever nations the LORD, your God, may have dispersed you, you ponder them in your heart:

2.verse: then, provided that you and your children return to the LORD, your God, and heed his voice with all your heart and all your soul, just as I now command you,

3.verse: the LORD, your God, will change your lot; and taking pity on you, he will again gather you from all the nations wherein he has scattered you.

4.verse: Though you may have been driven to the farthest corner of the world, even from there will the LORD, your God, gather you; even from there will he bring you back.

5.verse: The LORD, your God, will then bring you into the land which your fathers once occupied, that you too may occupy it, and he will make you more prosperous and numerous than your fathers.

6.verse: The LORD, your God, will circumcise your hearts and the hearts of your descendants, that you may love the LORD, your God, with all your heart and all your soul, and so may live.

7.verse: But all those curses the LORD, your God, will assign to your enemies and the foes who persecuted you.

8.verse: You, however, must again heed the LORD'S voice and carry out all his commandments which I now enjoin on you.

9.verse: Then the LORD, your God, will increase in more than goodly measure the returns from all your labors, the fruit of your womb, the offspring of your livestock, and the produce of your soil; for the LORD, your God, will again take delight in your prosperity, even as he took delight in your fathers',

10.verse: if only you heed the voice of the LORD, your God, and keep his commandments and statutes that are written in this book of the law, when you return to the LORD, your God, with all your heart and all your soul.

11.verse: "For this command which I enjoin on you today is not too mysterious and remote for you.

12.verse: It is not up in the sky, that you should say, 'Who will go up in the sky to get it for us and tell us of it, that we may carry it out?'

13.verse: Nor is it across the sea, that you should say, 'Who will cross the sea to get it for us and tell us of it, that we may carry it out?'

14.verse: No, it is something very near to you, already in your mouths and in your hearts; you have only to carry it out.

15.verse: "Here, then, I have today set before you life and prosperity, death and doom.

16.verse: If you obey the commandments of the LORD, your God, which I enjoin on you today, loving him, and walking in his ways, and keeping his commandments, statutes and decrees, you will live and grow numerous, and the LORD, your God, will bless you in the land you are entering to occupy.

17.verse: If, however, you turn away your hearts and will not listen, but are led astray and adore and serve other gods,

18.verse: I tell you now that you will certainly perish; you will not have a long life on the land which you are crossing the Jordan to enter and occupy.

19.verse: I call heaven and earth today to witness against you: I have set before you life and death, the blessing and the curse. Choose life, then, that you and your descendants may live,

20.verse: by loving the LORD, your God, heeding his voice, and holding fast to him. For that will mean life for you, a long life for you to live on the land which the LORD swore he would give to your fathers Abraham, Isaac and Jacob."

annotations.2: [11-14] God has revealed his will so clearly that ignorance of hislaw can be no excuse. St. Paul in Romans 10:6-10, applies these words to the ease with which we can come to faith and salvation in Christ
annotations.3: [14] In your mouths: that you may readily talk about it; cf Deut 6:7; 11:19. And in your hearts: that you may easily remember it; cf Deut 6:6; 11:18.

1.verse: "Then we turned and proceeded toward Bashan. But Og, king of Bashan, advanced against us with all his people to give battle at Edrei.

2.verse: The LORD, however, said to me, 'Do not be afraid of him, for I have delivered him into your hand with all his people and his land. Do to him as you did to Sihon, king of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon.'

3.verse: And thus the LORD, our God, delivered into our hands Og, king of Bashan, with all his people. We defeated him so completely that we left him no survivor.

4.verse: At that time we captured all his cities, none of them eluding our grasp, the whole region of Argob, the kingdom of Og in Bashan: sixty cities in all,

5.verse: to say nothing of the great number of unwalled towns. All the cities were fortified with high walls and gates and bars.

6.verse: As we had done to Sihon, king of Heshbon, so also here we doomed all the cities, with their men, women and children;

7.verse: but all the livestock and the loot of each city we took as booty for ourselves.

8.verse: "And so at that time we took from the two kings of the Amorites beyond the Jordan the territory from the Wadi Arnon to Mount Hermon

9.verse: (which is called Sirion by the Sidonians and Senir by the Amorites),

10.verse: comprising all the cities of the plateau and all Gilead and all the cities of the kingdom of Og in Bashan including Salecah and Edrei.

11.verse: (Og, king of Bashan, was the last remaining survivor of the Rephaim. He had a bed of iron, nine regular cubits long and four wide, which is still preserved in Rabbah of the Ammonites.)

12.verse: "When we occupied the land at that time, I gave Reuben and Gad the territory from Aroer, on the edge of the Wadi Arnon, halfway up into the highlands of Gilead, with the cities therein.

13.verse: The rest of Gilead and all of Bashan, the kingdom of Og, the whole Argob region, I gave to the half-tribe of Manasseh. (All this region of Bashan was once called a land of the Rephaim.

14.verse: Jair, a Manassehite clan, took all the region of Argob as far as the border of the Geshurites and Maacathites, and called it after his own name Bashan Havvoth-jair, the name it bears today.)

15.verse: To Machir I gave Gilead,

16.verse: and to Reuben and Gad the territory from Gilead to the Wadi Arnon - including the wadi bed and its banks - and to the Wadi Jabbok, which is the border of the Ammonites,

17.verse: as well as the Arabah with the Jordan and its eastern banks from Chinnereth to the Salt Sea of the Arabah, under the slopes of Pisgah.

18.verse: "At that time I charged them as follows 'The LORD, your God, has given you this land as your own. But all you troops equipped for battle must cross over in the vanguard of your brother Israelites.

19.verse: Only your wives and children, as well as your livestock, of which I know you have a large number, shall remain behind in the towns I have given you,

20.verse: until the LORD has settled your kinsmen as well, and they too possess the land which the LORD, your God, will give them on the other side of the Jordan. Then you may all return to the possessions I have given you.'

21.verse: "It was then that I instructed Joshua, 'Your eyes have seen all that the LORD, your God, has done to both these kings; so, too, will the LORD do to all the kingdoms which you will encounter over there.

22.verse: Fear them not, for the LORD, your God, will fight for you.'

23.verse: "And it was then that I besought the LORD,

24.verse: 'O Lord GOD, you have begun to show to your servant your greatness and might. For what god in heaven or on earth can perform deeds as mighty as yours?

25.verse: Ah, let me cross over and see this good land beyond the Jordan, this fine hill country, and the Lebanon!'

26.verse: But the LORD was angry with me on your account and would not hear me. 'Enough!' the LORD said to me. 'Speak to me no more of this.

27.verse: Go up to the top of Pisgah and look out to the west, and to the north, and to the south, and to the east. Look well, for you shall not cross this Jordan.

28.verse: Commission Joshua, and encourage and strengthen him, for he shall cross at the head of this people and shall put them in possession of the land you are to see.'

29.verse: This was while we were in the ravine opposite Beth-peor.
