1.verse: "At that time the LORD said to me, 'Cut two tablets of stone like the former; then come up the mountain to me. Also make an ark of wood.

2.verse: I will write upon the tablets the commandments that were on the former tablets that you broke, and you shall place them in the ark.'

3.verse: So I made an ark of acacia wood, and cut two tablets of stone like the former, and went up the mountain carrying the two tablets.

4.verse: The LORD then wrote on them, as he had written before, the ten commandments which he spoke to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire on the day of the assembly. After the LORD had given them to me,

5.verse: I turned and came down the mountain, and placed the tablets in the ark I had made. There they have remained, in keeping with the command the LORD gave me.

6.verse: (The Israelites set out from Beeroth Bene-jaakan for Moserah, where Aaron died and was buried, his son Eleazar succeeding him in the priestly office.

7.verse: From there they set out for Gudgodah, and from Gudgodah for Jotbathah, a region where there is water in the wadies.)

8.verse: "At that time the LORD set apart the tribe of Levi to carry the ark of the covenant of the LORD, to be in attendance before the LORD and minister to him, and to give blessings in his name, as they have done to this day.

9.verse: For this reason, Levi has no share in the heritage with his brothers; the LORD himself is his heritage, as the LORD, your God, has told him.

10.verse: "After I had spent these other forty days and forty nights on the mountain, and the LORD had once again heard me and decided not to destroy you,

11.verse: he said to me, 'Go now and set out at the head of your people, that they may enter in and occupy the land which I swore to their fathers I would give them.'

12.verse: "And now, Israel, what does the LORD, your God, ask of you but to fear the LORD, your God, and follow his ways exactly, to love and serve the LORD, your God, with all your heart and all your soul,

13.verse: to keep the commandments and statutes of the LORD which I enjoin on you today for your own good?

14.verse: Think! The heavens, even the highest heavens, belong to the LORD, your God, as well as the earth and everything on it.

15.verse: Yet in his love for your fathers the LORD was so attached to them as to choose you, their descendants, in preference to all other peoples, as indeed he has now done.

16.verse: Circumcise your hearts, therefore, and be no longer stiff-necked.

17.verse: For the LORD, your God, is the God of gods, the LORD of lords, the great God, mighty and awesome, who has no favorites, accepts no bribes;

18.verse: who executes justice for the orphan and the widow, and befriends the alien, feeding and clothing him.

19.verse: So you too must befriend the alien, for you were once aliens yourselves in the land of Egypt.

20.verse: The LORD, your God, shall you fear, and him shall you serve; hold fast to him and swear by his name.

21.verse: He is your glory, he, your God, who has done for you those great and terrible things which your own eyes have seen.

22.verse: Your ancestors went down to Egypt seventy strong, and now the LORD, your God, has made you as numerous as the stars of the sky.

annotations.1: [14] Even the highest heavens: literally, "and the heavens of the heavens"; compare the phrase, "the third heaven," in 2 Cor 12:2
annotations.2: [16] Circumcise your hearts: cf Deut 30:6; Jeremiah 4:4; Romans 2:29. The "uncircumcised heart" ( Lev 26:41; Jeremiah 9:25; Ezekiel 44:7, 9) is closed and unreceptive to divine grace and guidance, just as "uncircumcised ears" ( Jeremiah 6:10) are closed to sound, and "uncircumcised lips" ( Exodus 6:12, 30) do not open well in speech.

1.verse: Give ear, O heavens, while I speak; let the earth hearken to the words of my mouth!

2.verse: May my instruction soak in like the rain, and my discourse permeate like the dew, Like a downpour upon the grass, like a shower upon the crops.

3.verse: For I will sing the LORD'S renown. Oh, proclaim the greatness of our God!

4.verse: The Rock - how faultless are his deeds, how right all his ways! A faithful God, without deceit, how just and upright he is!

5.verse: Yet basely has he been treated by his degenerate children, a perverse and crooked race!

6.verse: Is the LORD to be thus repaid by you, O stupid and foolish people? Is he not your father who created you? Has he not made you and established you?

7.verse: Think back on the days of old, reflect on the years of age upon age. Ask your father and he will inform you, ask your elders and they will tell you:

8.verse: When the Most High assigned the nations their heritage, when he parceled out the descendants of Adam, He set up the boundaries of the peoples after the number of the sons of God;

9.verse: While the LORD'S own portion was Jacob, His hereditary share was Israel.

10.verse: He found them in a wilderness, a wasteland of howling desert. He shielded them and cared for them, guarding them as the apple of his eye.

11.verse: As an eagle incites its nestlings forth by hovering over its brood, So he spread his wings to receive them and bore them up on his pinions.

12.verse: The LORD alone was their leader, no strange god was with him.

13.verse: He had them ride triumphant over the summits of the land and live off the products of its fields, Giving them honey to suck from its rocks and olive oil from its hard, stony ground;

14.verse: Butter from its cows and milk from its sheep, with the fat of its lambs and rams; Its Bashan bulls and its goats, with the cream of its finest wheat; and the foaming blood of its grapes you drank.

15.verse: (So Jacob ate his fill,) the darling grew fat and frisky; you became fat and gross and gorged. They spurned the God who made them and scorned their saving Rock.

16.verse: They provoked him with strange gods and angered him with abominable idols.

17.verse: They offered sacrifice to demons, to "no-gods," to gods whom they had not known before, To newcomers just arrived, of whom their fathers had never stood in awe.

18.verse: You were unmindful of the Rock that begot you, You forgot the God who gave you birth.

19.verse: When the LORD saw this, he was filled with loathing and anger toward his sons and daughters.

20.verse: 'I will hide my face from them," he said, "and see what will then become of them. What a fickle race they are, sons with no loyalty in them!

21.verse: "Since they have provoked me with their 'no-god' and angered me with their vain idols, I will provoke them with a 'no-people'; with a foolish nation I will anger them.

22.verse: "For by my wrath a fire is enkindled that shall rage to the depths of the nether world, Consuming the earth with its yield, and licking with flames the roots of the mountains.

23.verse: I will spend on them woe upon woe and exhaust all my arrows against them:

24.verse: "Emaciating hunger and consuming fever and bitter pestilence, And the teeth of wild beasts I will send among them, with the venom of reptiles gliding in the dust.

25.verse: "Snatched away by the sword in the street and by sheer terror at home Shall be the youth and the maiden alike, the nursing babe as well as the hoary old man.

26.verse: "I would have said, 'I will make an end of them and blot out their name from men's memories,'

27.verse: Had I not feared the insolence of their enemies, feared that these foes would mistakenly boast, 'Our own hand won the victory; the LORD had nothing to do with it.'"

28.verse: For they are a people devoid of reason, having no understanding.

29.verse: If they had insight they would realize what happened, they would understand their future and say,

30.verse: "How could one man rout a thousand, or two men put ten thousand to flight, Unless it was because their Rock sold them and the LORD delivered them up?"

31.verse: Indeed, their "rock" is not like our Rock, and our foes are under condemnation.

32.verse: They are a branch of Sodom's vinestock, from the vineyards of Gomorrah. Poisonous are their grapes and bitter their clusters.

33.verse: Their wine is the venom of dragons and the cruel poison of cobras.

34.verse: "Is not this preserved in my treasury, sealed up in my storehouse,

35.verse: Against the day of vengeance and requital, against the time they lose their footing?" Close at hand is the day of their disaster and their doom is rushing upon them!

36.verse: Surely, the LORD shall do justice for his people; on his servants he shall have pity. When he sees their strength failing, and their protected and unprotected alike disappearing,

37.verse: He will say, "Where are their gods whom they relied on as their 'rock'?

38.verse: Let those who ate the fat of your sacrifices and drank the wine of your libations Rise up now and help you! Let them be your protection!

39.verse: "Learn then that I, I alone, am God, and there is no god besides me. It is I who bring both death and life, I who inflict wounds and heal them, and from my hand there is no rescue.

40.verse: "To the heavens I raise my hand and swear: As surely as I live forever,

41.verse: I will sharpen my flashing sword, and my hand shall lay hold of my quiver. "With vengeance I will repay my foes and requite those who hate me.

42.verse: I will make my arrows drunk with blood, and my sword shall gorge itself with flesh - With the blood of the slain and the captured, Flesh from the heads of the enemy leaders."

43.verse: Exult with him, you heavens, glorify him, all you angels of God; For he avenges the blood of his servants and purges his people's land.

44.verse: So Moses, together with Joshua, son of Nun, went and recited all the words of this song for the people to hear.

45.verse: When Moses had finished speaking all these words to all Israel,

46.verse: he said, "Take to heart all the warning which I have now given you and which you must impress on your children, that you may carry out carefully every word of this law.

47.verse: For this is no trivial matter for you; rather, it means your very life, since it is by this means that you are to enjoy a long life on the land which you will cross the Jordan to occupy."

48.verse: On that very day the LORD said to Moses,

49.verse: "Go up on Mount Nebo, here in the Abarim Mountains (it is in the land of Moab facing Jericho), and view the land of Canaan, which I am giving to the Israelites as their possession.

50.verse: Then you shall die on the mountain you have climbed, and shall be taken to your people, just as your brother Aaron died on Mount Hor and there was taken to his people;

51.verse: because both of you broke faith with me among the Israelites at the waters of Meribath-kadesh in the desert of Zin by failing to manifest my sanctity among the Israelites.

52.verse: You may indeed view the land at a distance, but you shall not enter that land which I am giving to the Israelites."

annotations.1: [1-43] In the style of the great prophets, the speaker is often God himself. The whole song is a poetic sermon, having for its theme God's benefits to Israel ( Deut 32:1-14) and Israel's ingratitude and idolatry in turning to the gods of the pagans, which sins will be punished by the pagans themselves ( Deut 32:15-29); in turn, the foolish pride of the pagans will be punished, and the Lord's honor will be vindicated ( Deut 32:30-43)
annotations.2: [8] The sons of God: the angels; cf Job 1:6; 2:1; 38:7; Psalm 89:6-7. Here the various nations are portrayed as having their respective guardian angels. Cf Daniel 10:20-21; 12:1
annotations.3: [13] The land: Canaan
annotations.4: [14] Bashan: a fertile grazing land east of the Jordan, famous for its strong cattle. Cf Psalm 22:13; Ezekiel 39:18; Amos 4:1
annotations.5: [15] The darling: a probable meaning of the Hebrew word yeshurun, a term of endearment for "Israel." Cf Deut 33:5, 26; Isaiah 44:2
annotations.6: [28-35] The reference is to the pagan nations, not to Israel
annotations.7: [36] Their protected and unprotected: the meaning of the Hebrew is uncertain; according to some, the idea is "slaves and freemen."

1.verse: "Now, Israel, hear the statutes and decrees which I am teaching you to observe, that you may live, and may enter in and take possession of the land which the LORD, the God of your fathers, is giving you.

2.verse: In your observance of the commandments of the LORD, your God, which I enjoin upon you, you shall not add to what I command you nor subtract from it.

3.verse: You have seen with your own eyes what the LORD did at Baal-peor: the LORD, your God, destroyed from your midst everyone that followed the Baal of Peor;

4.verse: but you, who clung to the LORD, your God, are all alive today.

5.verse: Therefore, I teach you the statutes and decrees as the LORD, my God, has commanded me, that you may observe them in the land you are entering to occupy.

6.verse: Observe them carefully, for thus will you give evidence of your wisdom and intelligence to the nations, who will hear of all these statutes and say, 'This great nation is truly a wise and intelligent people.'

7.verse: For what great nation is there that has gods so close to it as the LORD, our God, is to us whenever we call upon him?

8.verse: Or what great nation has statutes and decrees that are as just as this whole law which I am setting before you today?

9.verse: "However, take care and be earnestly on your guard not to forget the things which your own eyes have seen, nor let them slip from your memory as long as you live, but teach them to your children and to your children's children.

10.verse: There was the day on which you stood before the LORD, your God, at Horeb, and he said to me, 'Assemble the people for me; I will have them hear my words, that they may learn to fear me as long as they live in the land and may so teach their children.'

11.verse: You came near and stood at the foot of the mountain, which blazed to the very sky with fire and was enveloped in a dense black cloud.

12.verse: Then the LORD spoke to you from the midst of the fire. You heard the sound of the words, but saw no form; there was only a voice.

13.verse: He proclaimed to you his covenant, which he commanded you to keep: the ten commandments, which he wrote on two tablets of stone.

14.verse: The LORD charged me at that time to teach you the statutes and decrees which you are to observe over in the land you will occupy.

15.verse: "You saw no form at all on the day the LORD spoke to you at Horeb from the midst of the fire. Be strictly on your guard, therefore,

16.verse: not to degrade yourselves by fashioning an idol to represent any figure, whether it be the form of a man or a woman,

17.verse: of any animal on the earth or of any bird that flies in the sky,

18.verse: of anything that crawls on the ground or of any fish in the waters under the earth.

19.verse: And when you look up to the heavens and behold the sun or the moon or any star among the heavenly hosts, do not be led astray into adoring them and serving them. These the LORD, your God, has let fall to the lot of all other nations under the heavens;

20.verse: but you he has taken and led out of that iron foundry, Egypt, that you might be his very own people, as you are today.

21.verse: Since the LORD was angered against me on your account and swore that I should not cross the Jordan nor enter the good land which he is giving you as a heritage,

22.verse: I myself shall die in this country without crossing the Jordan; but you will cross over and take possession of that good land.

23.verse: Take heed, therefore, lest, forgetting the covenant which the LORD, your God, has made with you, you fashion for yourselves against his command an idol in any form whatsoever.

24.verse: For the LORD, your God, is a consuming fire, a jealous God.

25.verse: "When you have children and grandchildren, and have grown old in the land, should you then degrade yourselves by fashioning an idol in any form and by this evil done in his sight provoke the LORD, your God,

26.verse: I call heaven and earth this day to witness against you, that you shall all quickly perish from the land which you will occupy when you cross the Jordan. You shall not live in it for any length of time but shall be promptly wiped out.

27.verse: The LORD will scatter you among the nations, and there shall remain but a handful of you among the nations to which the LORD will lead you.

28.verse: There you shall serve gods fashioned by the hands of man out of wood and stone, gods which can neither see nor hear, neither eat nor smell.

29.verse: Yet there too you shall seek the LORD, your God; and you shall indeed find him when you search after him with your whole heart and your whole soul.

30.verse: In your distress, when all these things shall have come upon you, you shall finally return to the LORD, your God, and heed his voice.

31.verse: Since the LORD, your God, is a merciful God, he will not abandon and destroy you, nor forget the covenant which under oath he made with your fathers.

32.verse: "Ask now of the days of old, before your time, ever since God created man upon the earth; ask from one end of the sky to the other: Did anything so great ever happen before? Was it ever heard of?

33.verse: Did a people ever hear the voice of God speaking from the midst of fire, as you did, and live?

34.verse: Or did any god venture to go and take a nation for himself from the midst of another nation, by testings, by signs and wonders, by war, with his strong hand and outstretched arm, and by great terrors, all of which the LORD, your God, did for you in Egypt before your very eyes?

35.verse: All this you were allowed to see that you might know the LORD is God and there is no other.

36.verse: Out of the heavens he let you hear his voice to discipline you; on earth he let you see his great fire, and you heard him speaking out of the fire.

37.verse: For love of your fathers he chose their descendants and personally led you out of Egypt by his great power,

38.verse: driving out of your way nations greater and mightier than you, so as to bring you in and to make their land your heritage, as it is today.

39.verse: This is why you must now know, and fix in your heart, that the LORD is God in the heavens above and on earth below, and that there is no other.

40.verse: You must keep his statutes and commandments which I enjoin on you today, that you and your children after you may prosper, and that you may have long life on the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you forever."

41.verse: Then Moses set apart three cities in the region east of the Jordan,

42.verse: that a homicide might take refuge there if he unwittingly killed his neighbor to whom he had previously borne no malice, and that he might save his life by fleeing to one of these cities:

43.verse: Bezer in the desert, in the region of the plateau, for the Reubenites; Ramoth in Gilead for the Gadites; and Golan in Bashan for the Manassehites.

44.verse: This is the law which Moses set before the Israelites.

45.verse: These are the ordinances, statutes and decrees which he proclaimed to them when they had come out of Egypt

46.verse: and were beyond the Jordan in the ravine opposite Beth-peor, in the land of Sihon, king of the Amorites, who dwelt in Heshbon and whom Moses and the Israelites defeated after coming out of Egypt.

47.verse: They occupied his land and the land of Og, king of Bashan, as well - the land of these two kings of the Amorites in the region east of the Jordan:

48.verse: from Aroer on the edge of the Wadi Arnon to Mount Sion (that is Hermon)

49.verse: and all the Arabah east of the Jordan, as far as the Arabah Sea under the slopes of Pisgah.

annotations.1: [10] Beginning here and continuing on for several verses (at least to the end of v Deut 4:14) is the "reminiscence," the account of the things that the Israelites should recall and teach their children
annotations.2: [20] Egypt is called an iron foundry, or furnace for smelting iron, because God allowed the Israelites to be afflicted there for the sake of their spiritual purification; the same expression for Egypt occurs also in 1 Kings 8:51; Jeremiah 11:4; compare the expression, "the furnace of affliction," in Isaiah 48:10
annotations.3: [25] Grown old: Israel will lose the freshness of its youthful fervor
annotations.4: [34] Testings: the demonstrations of God's power as in the ten great plagues of Egypt; cf Deut 7:19; 29:2
