1.verse: "The whole priestly tribe of Levi shall have no share in the heritage with Israel; they shall live on the oblations of the LORD and the portions due to him.

2.verse: Levi shall have no heritage among his brothers; the LORD himself is his heritage, as he has told him.

3.verse: The priests shall have a right to the following things from the people: from those who are offering a sacrifice, whether the victim is from the herd or from the flock, the priest shall receive the shoulder, the jowls and the stomach.

4.verse: You shall also give him the first fruits of your grain and wine and oil, as well as the first fruits of the shearing of your flock;

5.verse: for the LORD, your God, has chosen him and his sons out of all your tribes to be always in attendance to minister in the name of the LORD.

6.verse: "When a Levite goes from one of your communities anywhere in Israel in which he ordinarily resides, to visit, as his heart may desire, the place which the LORD chooses,

7.verse: he may minister there in the name of the LORD, his God, like all his fellow Levites who are in attendance there before the LORD.

8.verse: He shall then receive the same portions to eat as the rest, along with his monetary offerings and heirlooms.

9.verse: "When you come into the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you, you shall not learn to imitate the abominations of the peoples there.

10.verse: Let there not be found among you anyone who immolates his son or daughter in the fire, nor a fortune-teller, soothsayer, charmer, diviner,

11.verse: or caster of spells, nor one who consults ghosts and spirits or seeks oracles from the dead.

12.verse: Anyone who does such things is an abomination to the LORD, and because of such abominations the LORD, your God, is driving these nations out of your way.

13.verse: You, however, must be altogether sincere toward the LORD, your God.

14.verse: Though these nations whom you are to dispossess listen to their soothsayers and fortune-tellers, the LORD, your God, will not permit you to do so.

15.verse: "A prophet like me will the LORD, your God, raise up for you from among your own kinsmen; to him you shall listen.

16.verse: This is exactly what you requested of the LORD, your God, at Horeb on the day of the assembly, when you said, 'Let us not again hear the voice of the LORD, our God, nor see this great fire any more, lest we die.'

17.verse: And the LORD said to me, 'This was well said.

18.verse: I will raise up for them a prophet like you from among their kinsmen, and will put my words into his mouth; he shall tell them all that I command him.

19.verse: If any man will not listen to my words which he speaks in my name, I myself will make him answer for it.

20.verse: But if a prophet presumes to speak in my name an oracle that I have not commanded him to speak, or speaks in the name of other gods, he shall die.'

21.verse: "If you say to yourselves, 'How can we recognize an oracle which the LORD has spoken?',

22.verse: know that, even though a prophet speaks in the name of the LORD, if his oracle is not fulfilled or verified, it is an oracle which the LORD did not speak. The prophet has spoken it presumptuously, and you shall have no fear of him.

annotations.1: [10-11] Immolates his son or daughter in the fire: to Molech. See note on Lev 18:21. Such human sacrifices are classed here with other pagan superstitions because they were believed to possess magical powers for averting a calamity; cf 2 Kings 3:27. Three other forms of superstition are listed here: augury (by a fortune-teller, a soothsayer or a diviner): black magic (by a charmer . . . or caster of spells); and necromancy (by one who consults ghosts and spirits or seeks oracles from the dead)
annotations.2: [15] A prophet like me: from the context (opposition to the pagan soothsayers) it seems that Moses is referring in general to all the true prophets who were to succeed him. But since Christ is the Great Prophet in whom the prophetic office finds its fulfillment and completion, this passage was understood in a special Messianic sense both by the Jews ( John 6:14; 7:40) and by the Apostles ( Acts 3:22; 7:37).

1.verse: "When you go out to war against your enemies and you see horses and chariots and an army greater than your own, do not be afraid of them, for the LORD, your God, who brought you up from the land of Egypt, will be with you.

2.verse: "When you are about to go into battle, the priest shall come forward and say to the soldiers:

3.verse: 'Hear, O Israel! Today you are going into battle against your enemies. Be not weakhearted or afraid; be neither alarmed nor frightened by them.

4.verse: For it is the LORD, your God, who goes with you to fight for you against your enemies and give you victory.'

5.verse: "Then the officials shall say to the soldiers, 'Is there anyone who has built a new house and not yet had the housewarming? Let him return home, lest he die in battle and another dedicate it.

6.verse: Is there anyone who has planted a vineyard and never yet enjoyed its fruits? Let him return home, lest he die in battle and another enjoy its fruits in his stead.

7.verse: Is there anyone who has betrothed a woman and not yet taken her as his wife? Let him return home, lest he die in battle and another take her to wife.'

8.verse: In fine, the officials shall say to the soldiers, 'Is there anyone who is afraid and weakhearted? Let him return home, lest he make his fellows as fainthearted as himself.'

9.verse: "When the officials have finished speaking to the soldiers, military officers shall be appointed over the army.

10.verse: "When you march up to attack a city, first offer it terms of peace.

11.verse: If it agrees to your terms of peace and opens its gates to you, all the people to be found in it shall serve you in forced labor.

12.verse: But if it refuses to make peace with you and instead offers you battle, lay siege to it,

13.verse: and when the LORD, your God, delivers it into your hand, put every male in it to the sword;

14.verse: but the women and children and livestock and all else in it that is worth plundering you may take as your booty, and you may use this plunder of your enemies which the LORD, your God, has given you.

15.verse: "That is how you shall deal with any city at a considerable distance from you, which does not belong to the peoples of this land.

16.verse: But in the cities of those nations which the LORD, your God, is giving you as your heritage, you shall not leave a single soul alive.

17.verse: You must doom them all - the Hittites, Amorites, Canaanites, Perizzites, Hivites and Jebusites - as the LORD, your God, has commanded you,

18.verse: lest they teach you to make any such abominable offerings as they make to their gods, and you thus sin against the LORD, your God.

19.verse: "When you are at war with a city and have to lay siege to it for a long time before you capture it, you shall not destroy its trees by putting an ax to them. You may eat their fruit, but you must not cut down the trees. After all, are the trees of the field men, that they should be included in your siege?

20.verse: However, those trees which you know are not fruit trees you may destroy, cutting them down to build siegeworks with which to reduce the city that is resisting you.

1.verse: "Hear, O Israel! You are now about to cross the Jordan to enter in and dispossess nations greater and stronger than yourselves, having large cities fortified to the sky,

2.verse: the Anakim, a people great and tall. You know of them and have heard it said of them, 'Who can stand up against the Anakim?'

3.verse: Understand, then, today that it is the LORD, your God, who will cross over before you as a consuming fire; he it is who will reduce them to nothing and subdue them before you, so that you can drive them out and destroy them quickly, as the LORD promised you.

4.verse: After the LORD, your God, has thrust them out of your way, do not say to yourselves, 'It is because of my merits that the LORD has brought me in to possess this land'; for it is really because of the wickedness of these nations that the LORD is driving them out before you.

5.verse: No, it is not because of your merits or the integrity of your heart that you are going in to take possession of their land; but the LORD, your God, is driving these nations out before you on account of their wickedness and in order to keep the promise which he made on oath to your fathers, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob.

6.verse: Understand this, therefore: it is not because of your merits that the LORD, your God, is giving you this good land to possess, for you are a stiff-necked people.

7.verse: "Bear in mind and do not forget how you angered the LORD, your God, in the desert. From the day you left the land of Egypt until you arrived in this place, you have been rebellious toward the LORD.

8.verse: At Horeb you so provoked the LORD that he was angry enough to destroy you,

9.verse: when I had gone up the mountain to receive the stone tablets of the covenant which the LORD made with you. Meanwhile I stayed on the mountain forty days and forty nights without eating or drinking,

10.verse: till the LORD gave me the two tablets of stone inscribed, by God's own finger, with a copy of all the words that the LORD spoke to you on the mountain from the midst of the fire on the day of the assembly.

11.verse: Then, at the end of the forty days and forty nights, when the LORD had given me the two stone tablets of the covenant,

12.verse: he said to me, 'Go down from here now, quickly, for your people whom you have brought out of Egypt have become depraved; they have already turned aside from the way I pointed out to them and have made for themselves a molten idol.

13.verse: I have seen now how stiff-necked this people is,' the LORD said to me.

14.verse: 'Let me be, that I may destroy them and blot out their name from under the heavens. I will then make of you a nation mightier and greater than they.'

15.verse: "When I had come down again from the blazing, fiery mountain, with the two tablets of the covenant in both my hands,

16.verse: I saw how you had sinned against the LORD, your God: you had already turned aside from the way which the LORD had pointed out to you by making for yourselves a molten calf!

17.verse: Raising the two tablets with both hands I threw them from me and broke them before your eyes.

18.verse: Then, as before, I lay prostrate before the LORD for forty days and forty nights without eating or drinking, because of all the sin you had committed in the sight of the LORD and the evil you had done to provoke him.

19.verse: For I dreaded the fierce anger of the LORD against you: his wrath would destroy you. Yet once again the LORD listened to me.

20.verse: With Aaron, too, the LORD was deeply angry, and would have killed him had I not prayed for him also at that time.

21.verse: Then, taking the calf, the sinful object you had made, and fusing it with fire, I ground it down to powder as fine as dust, which I threw into the wadi that went down the mountainside.

22.verse: "At Taberah, at Massah, and at Kibroth-hattaavah likewise, you provoked the LORD to anger.

23.verse: And when he sent you up from Kadesh-barnea to take possession of the land he was giving you, you rebelled against this command of the LORD, your God, and would not trust or obey him.

24.verse: Ever since I have known you, you have been rebels against the LORD.

25.verse: "Those forty days, then, and forty nights, I lay prostrate before the LORD, because he had threatened to destroy you.

26.verse: This was my prayer to him: O Lord GOD, destroy not your people, the heritage which your majesty has ransomed and brought out of Egypt with your strong hand.

27.verse: Remember your servants, Abraham, Isaac and Jacob. Look not upon the stubbornness of this people nor upon their wickedness and sin,

28.verse: lest the people from whose land you have brought us say, 'The LORD was not able to bring them into the land he promised them'; or 'Out of hatred for them, he brought them out to slay them in the desert.'

29.verse: They are, after all, your people and your heritage, whom you have brought out by your great power and with your outstretched arm.

1.verse: "When you have come into the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you as a heritage, and have occupied it and settled in it,

2.verse: you shall take some first fruits of the various products of the soil which you harvest from the land which the LORD, your God, gives you, and putting them in a basket, you shall go to the place which the LORD, your God, chooses for the dwelling place of his name.

3.verse: There you shall go to the priest in office at that time and say to him, 'Today I acknowledge to the LORD, my God, that I have indeed come into the land which he swore to our fathers he would give us.'

4.verse: The priest shall then receive the basket from you and shall set it in front of the altar of the LORD, your God.

5.verse: Then you shall declare before the LORD, your God, 'My father was a wandering Aramean who went down to Egypt with a small household and lived there as an alien. But there he became a nation great, strong and numerous.

6.verse: When the Egyptians maltreated and oppressed us, imposing hard labor upon us,

7.verse: we cried to the LORD, the God of our fathers, and he heard our cry and saw our affliction, our toil and our oppression.

8.verse: He brought us out of Egypt with his strong hand and outstretched arm, with terrifying power, with signs and wonders;

9.verse: and bringing us into this country, he gave us this land flowing with milk and honey.

10.verse: Therefore, I have now brought you the first fruits of the products of the soil which you, O LORD, have given me.' And having set them before the LORD, your God, you shall bow down in his presence.

11.verse: Then you and your family, together with the Levite and the aliens who live among you, shall make merry over all these good things which the LORD, your God, has given you.

12.verse: "When you have finished setting aside all the tithes of your produce in the third year, the year of the tithes, and you have given them to the Levite, the alien, the orphan and the widow, that they may eat their fill in your own community,

13.verse: you shall declare before the LORD, your God, 'I have purged my house of the sacred portion and I have given it to the Levite, the alien, the orphan and the widow, just as you have commanded me. In this I have not broken or forgotten any of your commandments:

14.verse: I have not eaten any of the tithe as a mourner; I have not brought any of it out as one unclean; I have not offered any of it to the dead. I have thus hearkened to the voice of the LORD, my God, doing just as you have commanded me.

15.verse: Look down, then, from heaven, your holy abode, and bless your people Israel and the soil you have given us in the land flowing with milk and honey which you promised on oath to our fathers.'

16.verse: "This day the LORD, your God, commands you to observe these statutes and decrees. Be careful, then, to observe them with all your heart and with all your soul.

17.verse: Today you are making this agreement with the LORD: he is to be your God and you are to walk in his ways and observe his statutes, commandments and decrees, and to hearken to his voice.

18.verse: And today the LORD is making this agreement with you: you are to be a people peculiarly his own, as he promised you; and provided you keep all his commandments,

19.verse: he will then raise you high in praise and renown and glory above all other nations he has made, and you will be a people sacred to the LORD, your God, as he promised."

annotations.1: [5] Aramean: either in reference to the origin of the patriarchs from Aram Naharaim (cf Genesis 24:10; 25:20; 28:5; 31:20, 24), or merely in the sense of "nomad," in the same way as "Arab" was later used; cf Jeremiah 3:2
annotations.2: [12] And you have given them to the Levite . . . : as prescribed in Deut 14:28-29
annotations.3: [14] These are allusions to pagan religious practices.

1.verse: "A man shall not marry his father's wife, nor shall he dishonor his father's bed.

2.verse: "No one whose testicles have been crushed or whose penis has been cut off may be admitted into the community of the LORD.

3.verse: No child of an incestuous union may be admitted into the community of the LORD, nor any descendant of his even to the tenth generation.

4.verse: No Ammonite or Moabite may ever be admitted into the community of the LORD, nor any descendants of theirs even to the tenth generation,

5.verse: because they would not succor you with food and water on your journey after you left Egypt, and because Moab hired Balaam, son of Beor, from Pethor in Aram Naharaim, to curse you;

6.verse: though the LORD, your God, would not listen to Balaam and turned his curse into a blessing for you, because he loves you.

7.verse: Never promote their peace and prosperity as long as you live.

8.verse: But do not abhor the Edomite, since he is your brother, nor the Egyptian, since you were an alien in his country.

9.verse: Children born to them may in the third generation be admitted into the community of the LORD.

10.verse: "When you are in camp during an expedition against your enemies, you shall keep yourselves from everything offensive.

11.verse: If one of you becomes unclean because of a nocturnal emission, he shall go outside the camp, and not return until,

12.verse: toward evening, he has bathed in water; then, when the sun has set, he may come back into the camp.

13.verse: Outside the camp you shall have a place set aside to be used as a latrine.

14.verse: You shall also keep a trowel in your equipment and with it, when you go outside to ease nature, you shall first dig a hole and afterward cover up your excrement.

15.verse: Since the LORD, your God, journeys along within your camp to defend you and to put your enemies at your mercy, your camp must be holy; otherwise, if he sees anything indecent in your midst, he will leave your company.

16.verse: "You shall not hand over to his master a slave who has taken refuge from him with you.

17.verse: Let him live with you wherever he chooses, in any one of your communities that pleases him. Do not molest him.

18.verse: "There shall be no temple harlot among the Israelite women, nor a temple prostitute among the Israelite men.

19.verse: You shall not offer a harlot's fee or a dog's price as any kind of votive offering in the house of the LORD, your God; both these things are an abomination to the LORD, your God.

20.verse: "You shall not demand interest from your countrymen on a loan of money or of food or of anything else on which interest is usually demanded.

21.verse: You may demand interest from a foreigner, but not from your countryman, so that the LORD, your God, may bless you in all your undertakings on the land you are to enter and occupy.

22.verse: "When you make a vow to the LORD, your God, you shall not delay in fulfilling it; otherwise you will be held guilty, for the LORD, your God, is strict in requiring it of you.

23.verse: Should you refrain from making a vow, you will not be held guilty.

24.verse: But you must keep your solemn word and fulfill the votive offering you have freely promised to the LORD.

25.verse: "When you go through your neighbor's vineyard, you may eat as many of his grapes as you wish, but do not put them in your basket.

26.verse: When you go through your neighbor's grainfield, you may pluck some of the ears with your hand, but do not put a sickle to your neighbor's grain.

annotations.1: [1] Father's wife: stepmother. Dishonor: cf Deut 27:20
annotations.2: [17] In any one of your communities: from this it would seem that the slave in question is a fugitive from a foreign country
annotations.3: [18-19] The pagans believed that they could enter into special relationship with their gods and goddesses by having sexual relations with the pagan priests and priestesses who prostituted themselves for this purpose. The money paid for this was considered a sort of votive offering made to the pagan sanctuary. Such abominations were naturally forbidden in Israel. A dog's price: the money paid to the pagan priest for his indecent service.

1.verse: This is the blessing which Moses, the man of God, pronounced upon the Israelites before he died.

2.verse: He said: "The LORD came from Sinai and dawned on his people from Seir; He shone forth from Mount Paran and advanced from Meribath-kadesh, While at his right hand a fire blazed forth and his wrath devastated the nations.

3.verse: But all his holy ones were in his hand; they followed at his feet and he bore them up on his pinions.

4.verse: A law he gave to us; he made the community of Jacob his domain,

5.verse: and he became king of his darling. When the chiefs of the people assembled and the tribes of Israel came together.

6.verse: "May Reuben live and not die out, but let his men be few."

7.verse: The following is for Judah. He said: "The LORD hears the cry of Judah; you will bring him to his people. His own hands defend his cause and you will be his help against his foes."

8.verse: Of Levi he said: "To Levi belong your Thummim, to the man of your favor your Urim; For you put him to the test at Massah and you contended with him at the waters of Meribah.

9.verse: He said of his father, 'I regard him not'; his brothers he would not acknowledge, and his own children he refused to recognize. Thus the Levites keep your words, and your covenant they uphold.

10.verse: They promulgate your decisions to Jacob and your law to Israel. They bring the smoke of sacrifice to your nostrils, and burnt offerings to your altar.

11.verse: Bless, O LORD, his possessions and accept the ministry of his hands. Break the backs of his adversaries and of his foes, that they may not rise."

12.verse: Of Benjamin he said: "Benjamin is the beloved of the LORD, who shelters him all the day, while he abides securely at his breast."

13.verse: Of Joseph he said: "Blessed by the LORD is his land with the best of the skies above and of the abyss crouching beneath;

14.verse: With the best of the produce of the year, and the choicest sheaves of the months;

15.verse: With the finest gifts of the age-old mountains and the best from the timeless hills;

16.verse: With the best of the earth and its fullness, and the favor of him who dwells in the bush. These shall come upon the head of Joseph and upon the brow of the prince among his brothers,

17.verse: The majestic bull, his father's first-born, whose horns are those of the wild ox With which to gore the nations, even those at the ends of the earth." (These are the myriads of Ephraim, and these the thousands of Manasseh.)

18.verse: Of Zebulun he said: "Rejoice, O Zebulun, in your pursuits, and you, Issachar, in your tents!

19.verse: You who invite the tribes to the mountains where feasts are duly held, Because you suck up the abundance of the seas and the hidden treasures of the sand."

20.verse: Of Gad he said: "Blessed be he who has made Gad so vast! He lies there like a lion that has seized the arm and head of the prey.

21.verse: He saw that the best should be his when the princely portion was assigned, while the heads of the people were gathered. He carried out the justice of the LORD and his decrees respecting Israel."

22.verse: Of Dan he said: "Dan is a lion's whelp, that springs forth from Bashan!"

23.verse: Of Naphtali he said: "Naphtali is enriched with favors and filled with the blessings of the LORD; The lake and south of it are his possession!"

24.verse: Of Asher he said: "More blessed than the other sons be Asher! May he be the favorite among his brothers, as the oil of his olive trees runs over his feet!

25.verse: May your bolts be of iron and bronze; may your strength endure through all your days!"

26.verse: "There is no god like the God of the darling, who rides the heavens in his power, and rides the skies in his majesty;

27.verse: He spread out the primeval tent; he extended the ancient canopy. He drove the enemy out of your way and the Amorite he destroyed.

28.verse: Israel has dwelt securely, and the fountain of Jacob has been undisturbed In a land of grain and wine, where the heavens drip with dew.

29.verse: How fortunate you are, O Israel! Where else is a nation victorious in the LORD? The LORD is your saving shield, and his sword is your glory. Your enemies fawn upon you, as you stride upon their heights."

annotations.1: [2-5,26-29] These verses seem to form an independent hymn describing, in the form of a theophany, the conquest of Canaan. The first section of this hymn ( Deut 33:2-5) serves here as an introduction to the various "blessings"; the second section ( Deut 33:26-29), as their conclusion
annotations.2: [3] His holy ones were in his hand: the Israelites were protected by the Lord
annotations.3: [5,26] The darling: see note on Deut 32:15
annotations.4: [6] In keeping with the other blessings, probably this verse was once introduced by the phrase, "Of Reuben he said." It is to be noted that there is no blessing here for Simeon
annotations.5: [7] Bring him to his people: this probably refers to the isolated position of the tribe of Judah during the conquest of the Promised Land (cf Judges 1:17-19); according to some commentators the reference is to the divided kingdom
annotations.6: [8] Thummim . . . Urim: see note on Exodus 28:30
annotations.7: [9] The reference is probably to the Levites' slaughter of their brethren after the affair of the golden calf in the desert; cf Exodus 32:27-29
annotations.8: [16] Him who dwells in the bush: a title given to the Lord because of his appearance to Moses in the burning bush; cf Exodus 3
annotations.9: [19] The abundance of the seas: perhaps the wealth that comes from sea-borne trade or from fishing. The hidden treasures of the sand: possibly an allusion to the valuable purple dye extracted from certain marine shells found on the coast of northern Palestine
annotations.10: [21] The princely portion: Moses gave the tribe of Gad their land on the east of the Jordan only on condition that they would help the other tribes conquer the land west of the river; cf Numbers 32; Joshua 22
annotations.11: [22] The sense is, "May he leap up like a lion of Bashan"; the heavily wooded hills of Bashan were notorious for their lions, but the tribe of Dan was not settled in this region
annotations.12: [23] The lake: the Lake of Gennesaret on which the land of this tribe bordered
annotations.13: [24] The land of the tribe of Asher was covered with olive groves.

1.verse: Moses summoned all Israel and said to them, "Hear, O Israel, the statutes and decrees which I proclaim in your hearing this day, that you may learn them and take care to observe them.

2.verse: The LORD, our God, made a covenant with us at Horeb;

3.verse: not with our fathers did he make this covenant, but with us, all of us who are alive here this day.

4.verse: The LORD spoke with you face to face on the mountain from the midst of the fire.

5.verse: Since you were afraid of the fire and would not go up the mountain, I stood between the LORD and you at that time, to announce to you these words of the LORD:

6.verse: 'I, the LORD, am your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, that place of slavery.

7.verse: You shall not have other gods besides me.

8.verse: You shall not carve idols for yourselves in the shape of anything in the sky above or on the earth below or in the waters beneath the earth;

9.verse: you shall not bow down before them or worship them. For I, the LORD, your God, am a jealous God, inflicting punishments for their fathers' wickedness on the children of those who hate me, down to the third and fourth generation

10.verse: but bestowing mercy, down to the thousandth generation, on the children of those who love me and keep my commandments.

11.verse: 'You shall not take the name of the LORD, your God, in vain. For the LORD will not leave unpunished him who takes his name in vain.

12.verse: 'Take care to keep holy the sabbath day as the LORD, your God, commanded you.

13.verse: Six days you may labor and do all your work;

14.verse: but the seventh day is the sabbath of the LORD, your God. No work may be done then, whether by you, or your son or daughter, or your male or female slave, or your ox or ass or any of your beasts, or the alien who lives with you. Your male and female slave should rest as you do.

15.verse: For remember that you too were once slaves in Egypt, and the LORD, your God, brought you from there with his strong hand and outstretched arm. That is why the LORD, your God, has commanded you to observe the sabbath day.

16.verse: 'Honor your father and your mother, as the LORD, your God, has commanded you, that you may have a long life and prosperity in the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you.

17.verse: 'You shall not kill.

18.verse: 'You shall not commit adultery.

19.verse: 'You shall not steal.

20.verse: 'You shall not bear dishonest witness against your neighbor.

21.verse: 'You shall not covet your neighbor's wife. 'You shall not desire your neighbor's house or field, nor his male or female slave, nor his ox or ass, nor anything that belongs to him.'

22.verse: "These words, and nothing more, the LORD spoke with a loud voice to your entire assembly on the mountain from the midst of the fire and the dense cloud. He wrote them upon two tablets of stone and gave them to me.

23.verse: But when you heard the voice from the midst of the darkness, while the mountain was ablaze with fire, you came to me in the person of all your tribal heads and elders,

24.verse: and said, 'The LORD, our God, has indeed let us see his glory and his majesty! We have heard his voice from the midst of the fire and have found out today that a man can still live after God has spoken with him.

25.verse: But why should we die now? Surely this great fire will consume us. If we hear the voice of the LORD, our God, any more, we shall die.

26.verse: For what mortal has heard, as we have, the voice of the living God speaking from the midst of fire, and survived?

27.verse: Go closer, you, and hear all that the LORD, our God, will say, and then tell us what the LORD, our God, tells you; we will listen and obey.'

28.verse: "The LORD heard your words as you were speaking to me and said to me, 'I have heard the words these people have spoken to you, which are all well said.

29.verse: Would that they might always be of such a mind, to fear me and to keep all my commandments! Then they and their descendants would prosper forever.

30.verse: Go, tell them to return to their tents.

31.verse: Then you wait here near me and I will give you all the commandments, the statutes and decrees you must teach them, that they may observe them in the land which I am giving them to possess.'

32.verse: "Be careful, therefore, to do as the LORD, your God, has commanded you, not turning aside to the right or to the left,

33.verse: but following exactly the way prescribed for you by the LORD, your God, that you may live and prosper, and may have long life in the land which you are to occupy.

annotations.1: [9-10] God does not punish us for another's sins, but because of the solidarity of human society, the good or evil deeds of one generation may make their effects felt even in later generations. Yet note how God's mercy allows the good effects of virtue to last much longer than the bad effects of vice: a thousand generations compared to three or four.

1.verse: "You are children of the LORD, your God. You shall not gash yourselves nor shave the hair above your foreheads for the dead.

2.verse: For you are a people sacred to the LORD, your God, who has chosen you from all the nations on the face of the earth to be a people peculiarly his own.

3.verse: "You shall not eat any abominable thing.

4.verse: These are the animals you may eat: the ox, the sheep, the goat,

5.verse: the red deer, the gazelle, the roe deer, the ibex, the addax, the oryx, and the mountain sheep.

6.verse: Any animal that has hoofs you may eat, provided it is cloven-footed and chews the cud.

7.verse: But you shall not eat any of the following that only chew the cud or only have cloven hoofs: the camel, the hare and the rock badger, which indeed chew the cud, but do not have hoofs and are therefore unclean for you;

8.verse: and the pig, which indeed has hoofs and is cloven-footed, but does not chew the cud and is therefore unclean for you. Their flesh you shall not eat, and their dead bodies you shall not touch.

9.verse: "Of the various creatures that live in the water, whatever has both fins and scales you may eat,

10.verse: but all those that lack either fins or scales you shall not eat; they are unclean for you.

11.verse: "You may eat all clean birds.

12.verse: But you shall not eat any of the following: the eagle, the vulture, the osprey,

13.verse: the various kites and falcons,

14.verse: all the various species of crows,

15.verse: the ostrich, the nightjar, the gull, the various species of hawks,

16.verse: the owl, the screech owl, the ibis,

17.verse: the desert owl, the buzzard, the cormorant,

18.verse: the stork, the various species of herons, the hoopoe, and the bat.

19.verse: All winged insects, too, are unclean for you and shall not be eaten.

20.verse: But you may eat any clean winged creatures.

21.verse: "You must not eat any animal that has died of itself, for you are a people sacred to the LORD, your God. But you may give it to an alien who belongs to your community, and he may eat it, or you may sell it to a foreigner. "You shall not boil a kid in its mother's milk.

22.verse: "Each year you shall tithe all the produce that grows in the field you have sown;

23.verse: then in the place which the LORD, your God, chooses as the dwelling place of his name you shall eat in his presence your tithe of the grain, wine and oil, as well as the firstlings of your herd and flock, that you may learn always to fear the LORD, your God.

24.verse: If, however, the journey is too much for you and you are not able to bring your tithe, because the place which the LORD, your God, chooses for the abode of his name is too far for you, considering how the LORD has blessed you,

25.verse: you may exchange the tithe for money and, with the purse of money in hand, go to the place which the LORD, your God, chooses.

26.verse: You may then exchange the money for whatever you desire, oxen or sheep, wine or strong drink, or anything else you would enjoy, and there before the LORD, your God, you shall partake of it and make merry with your family.

27.verse: But do not neglect the Levite who belongs to your community, for he has no share in the heritage with you.

28.verse: "At the end of every third year you shall bring out all the tithes of your produce for that year and deposit them in community stores,

29.verse: that the Levite who has no share in the heritage with you, and also the alien, the orphan and the widow who belong to your community, may come and eat their fill; so that the LORD, your God, may bless you in all that you undertake.

annotations.1: [5] The gazelle, the addax, the oryx: species of antelopes. The ibex: a species of wild goat
annotations.2: [19-20] The apparent contradiction is to be resolved in the light of Lev 11:20-23: the unclean winged insects are those that walk on the ground; the clean winged creatures are those that leap on the ground, such as certain species of locusts
annotations.3: [21] Boil a kid in its mother's milk: see note on Exodus 23:19
annotations.4: [24] Considering how the LORD has blessed you: should the Israelite farmer be blessed with an abundant harvest, a tenth of this would be too much to transport for a great distance.

1.verse: "Love the LORD, your God, therefore, and always heed his charge: his statutes, decrees and commandments.

2.verse: It is not your children, who have not known it from experience, but you yourselves who must now understand the discipline of the LORD, your God; his majesty, his strong hand and outstretched arm;

3.verse: the signs and deeds he wrought among the Egyptians, on Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and on all his land;

4.verse: what he did to the Egyptian army and to their horses and chariots, engulfing them in the water of the Red Sea as they pursued you, and bringing ruin upon them even to this day;

5.verse: what he did for you in the desert until you arrived in this place;

6.verse: and what he did to the Reubenites Dathan and Abiram, sons of Eliab, when the ground opened its mouth and swallowed them up out of the midst of Israel, with their families and tents and every living thing that belonged to them.

7.verse: With your own eyes you have seen all these great deeds that the LORD has done.

8.verse: Keep all the commandments, then, which I enjoin on you today, that you may be strong enough to enter in and take possession of the land into which you are crossing,

9.verse: and that you may have long life on the land which the LORD swore to your fathers he would give to them and their descendants, a land flowing with milk and honey.

10.verse: "For the land which you are to enter and occupy is not like the land of Egypt from which you have come, where you would sow your seed and then water it by hand, as in a vegetable garden.

11.verse: No, the land into which you are crossing for conquest is a land of hills and valleys that drinks in rain from the heavens,

12.verse: a land which the LORD, your God, looks after; his eyes are upon it continually from the beginning of the year to the end.

13.verse: If, then, you truly heed my commandments which I enjoin on you today, loving and serving the LORD, your God, with all your heart and all your soul,

14.verse: I will give the seasonal rain to your land, the early rain and the late rain, that you may have your grain, wine and oil to gather in;

15.verse: and I will bring forth grass in your fields for your animals. Thus you may eat your fill.

16.verse: But be careful lest your heart be so lured away that you serve other gods and worship them.

17.verse: For then the wrath of the LORD will flare up against you and he will close up the heavens, so that no rain will fall, and the soil will not yield its crops, and you will soon perish from the good land he is giving you.

18.verse: "Therefore, take these words of mine into your heart and soul. Bind them at your wrist as a sign, and let them be a pendant on your forehead.

19.verse: Teach them to your children, speaking of them at home and abroad, whether you are busy or at rest.

20.verse: And write them on the doorposts of your houses and on your gates,

21.verse: so that, as long as the heavens are above the earth, you and your children may live on in the land which the LORD swore to your fathers he would give them.

22.verse: "For if you are careful to observe all these commandments I enjoin on you, loving the LORD, your God, and following his ways exactly, and holding fast to him,

23.verse: the LORD will drive all these nations out of your way, and you will dispossess nations greater and mightier than yourselves.

24.verse: Every place where you set foot shall be yours: from the desert and from Lebanon, from the Euphrates River to the Western Sea, shall be your territory.

25.verse: None shall stand up against you; the LORD, your God, will spread the fear and dread of you through any land where you set foot, as he promised you.

26.verse: "I set before you here, this day, a blessing and a curse:

27.verse: a blessing for obeying the commandments of the LORD, your God, which I enjoin on you today;

28.verse: a curse if you do not obey the commandments of the LORD, your God, but turn aside from the way I ordain for you today, to follow other gods, whom you have not known.

29.verse: When the LORD, your God, brings you into the land which you are to enter and occupy, then you shall pronounce the blessing on Mount Gerizim, the curse on Mount Ebal.

30.verse: (Are they not beyond the Jordan, on the other side of the western road in the country of the Canaanites who live in the Arabah, opposite the Gilgal beside the terebinth of Moreh?)

31.verse: For you are about to cross the Jordan to enter and occupy the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you. When, therefore, you take possession of it and settle there,

32.verse: be careful to observe all the statutes and decrees that I set before you today.

annotations.1: [13-15] As often in the Prophets, the discourse passes into the words of God himself. Cf Deut 7:4; 17:3; 28:20; 29:4, 5
annotations.2: [14] The early rain: the rains which begin in October or November and continue intermittently throughout the winter. The late rain: the heavy showers of March and April. In Palestine the crops are sown in the autumn and reaped in the spring
annotations.3: [24] The Western Sea: the Mediterranean
annotations.4: [29] You shall pronounce the blessing . . . the curse: for the full ceremony, see Deut 27-28. Gerizim . . . Ebal: adjacent mountains in Samaria with a deep ravine between them. Their summits command an excellent view of the entire country.

1.verse: Then Moses, with the elders of Israel, gave the people this order: "Keep all these commandments which I enjoin on you today.

2.verse: On the day you cross the Jordan into the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you, set up some large stones and coat them with plaster.

3.verse: Also write on them, at the time you cross, all the words of this law, that you may thus enter into the land flowing with milk and honey, which the LORD, your God, and the God of your fathers, is giving you as he promised you.

4.verse: When, moreover, you have crossed the Jordan, besides setting up on Mount Ebal these stones concerning which I command you today, and coating them with plaster,

5.verse: you shall also build to the LORD, your God, an altar made of stones that no iron tool has touched.

6.verse: You shall make this altar of the LORD, your God, with undressed stones, and shall offer on it holocausts to the LORD, your God.

7.verse: You shall also sacrifice peace offerings and eat them there, making merry before the LORD, your God.

8.verse: On the stones you shall inscribe all the words of this law very clearly."

9.verse: Moses, with the levitical priests, then said to all Israel: "Be silent, O Israel, and listen! This day you have become the people of the LORD, your God.

10.verse: You shall therefore hearken to the voice of the LORD, your God, and keep his commandments and statutes which I enjoin on you today."

11.verse: That same day Moses gave the people this order:

12.verse: "When you cross the Jordan, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Joseph and Benjamin shall stand on Mount Gerizim to pronounce blessings over the people,

13.verse: while Reuben, Gad, Asher, Zebulun, Dan and Naphtali shall stand on Mount Ebal to pronounce curses.

14.verse: "The Levites shall proclaim aloud to all the men of Israel:

15.verse: 'Cursed be the man who makes a carved or molten idol - an abomination to the LORD, the product of a craftsman's hands - and sets it up in secret!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

16.verse: 'Cursed be he who dishonors his father or his mother!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

17.verse: 'Cursed be he who moves his neighbor's landmarks!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

18.verse: 'Cursed be he who misleads a blind man on his way!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

19.verse: 'Cursed be he who violates the rights of the alien, the orphan or the widow!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

20.verse: 'Cursed be he who has relations with his father's wife, for he dishonors his father's bed!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

21.verse: 'Cursed be he who has relations with any animal!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

22.verse: 'Cursed be he who has relations with his sister or his half-sister!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

23.verse: 'Cursed be he who has relations with his mother-in-law!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

24.verse: 'Cursed be he who slays his neighbor in secret!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

25.verse: 'Cursed be he who accepts payment for slaying an innocent man!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

26.verse: 'Cursed be he who fails to fulfill any of the provisions of this law!' And all the people shall answer, 'Amen!'

annotations.1: [8] On the stones: cf Deut 27:3-4; not the stones of the altar
annotations.2: [15-26] Amen: see note on Numbers 5:22.

1.verse: "Observe the month of Abib by keeping the Passover of the LORD, your God, since it was in the month of Abib that he brought you by night out of Egypt.

2.verse: You shall offer the Passover sacrifice from your flock or your herd to the LORD, your God, in the place which he chooses as the dwelling place of his name.

3.verse: You shall not eat leavened bread with it. For seven days you shall eat with it only unleavened bread, the bread of affliction, that you may remember as long as you live the day of your departure from the land of Egypt; for in frightened haste you left the land of Egypt.

4.verse: Nothing leavened may be found in all your territory for seven days, and none of the meat which you sacrificed on the evening of the first day shall be kept overnight for the next day.

5.verse: "You may not sacrifice the Passover in any of the communities which the LORD, your God, gives you;

6.verse: only at the place which he chooses as the dwelling place of his name, and in the evening at sunset, on the anniversary of your departure from Egypt, shall you sacrifice the Passover.

7.verse: You shall cook and eat it at the place the LORD, your God, chooses; then in the morning you may return to your tents.

8.verse: For six days you shall eat unleavened bread, and on the seventh there shall be a solemn meeting in honor of the LORD, your God; on that day you shall not do any sort of work.

9.verse: "You shall count off seven weeks, computing them from the day when the sickle is first put to the standing grain.

10.verse: You shall then keep the feast of Weeks in honor of the LORD, your God, and the measure of your own freewill offering shall be in proportion to the blessing the LORD, your God, has bestowed on you.

11.verse: In the place which the LORD, your God, chooses as the dwelling place of his name, you shall make merry in his presence together with your son and daughter, your male and female slave, and the Levite who belongs to your community, as well as the alien, the orphan and the widow among you.

12.verse: Remember that you too were once slaves in Egypt, and carry out these statutes carefully.

13.verse: "You shall celebrate the feast of Booths for seven days, when you have gathered in the produce from your threshing floor and wine press.

14.verse: You shall make merry at your feast, together with your son and daughter, your male and female slave, and also the Levite, the alien, the orphan and the widow who belong to your community.

15.verse: For seven days you shall celebrate this pilgrim feast in honor of the LORD, your God, in the place which he chooses; since the LORD, your God, has blessed you in all your crops and in all your undertakings, you shall do nought but make merry.

16.verse: "Three times a year, then, every male among you shall appear before the LORD, your God, in the place which he chooses: at the feast of Unleavened Bread, at the feast of Weeks, and at the feast of Booths. No one shall appear before the LORD empty-handed,

17.verse: but each of you with as much as he can give, in proportion to the blessings which the LORD, your God, has bestowed on you.

18.verse: "You shall appoint judges and officials throughout your tribes to administer true justice for the people in all the communities which the LORD, your God, is giving you.

19.verse: You shall not distort justice; you must be impartial. You shall not take a bribe; for a bribe blinds the eyes even of the wise and twists the words even of the just.

20.verse: Justice and justice alone shall be your aim, that you may have life and may possess the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you.

21.verse: "You shall not plant a sacred pole of any kind of wood beside the altar of the LORD, your God, which you will build;

22.verse: nor shall you erect a sacred pillar, such as the LORD, your God, detests.

annotations.1: [1] Abib: "ear of grain, ripe grain," the name of the month in which the barley harvest fell, corresponding to our March and April; at a later period this month received the Babylonian name of "Nisan.&quot
annotations.2: [10] Feast of Weeks: later known more commonly as "Pentecost.&quot
annotations.3: [13] See note on Lev 23:34
annotations.4: [21- 17:7] This section seems to be out of its proper place, since it interrupts the natural sequence of the laws for the judges ( Deut 16:18-20; 17:8-13). It probably belongs to the similar section, Deut 12:29- 14:2.
annotations.5: [21-22] Sacred pole . . . sacred pillar: see note on Exodus 34:13.

1.verse: "When the LORD, your God, removes the nations whose land he is giving you, and you have taken their place and are settled in their cities and houses,

2.verse: you shall set apart three cities in the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you to occupy.

3.verse: You shall thereby divide into three regions the land which the LORD, your God, will give you as a heritage, and so arrange the routes that every homicide will be able to find a refuge.

4.verse: "It is in the following case that a homicide may take refuge in such a place to save his life: when someone unwittingly kills his neighbor to whom he had previously borne no malice.

5.verse: For example, if he goes with his neighbor to a forest to cut wood, and as he swings his ax to fell a tree, its head flies off the handle and hits his neighbor a mortal blow, he may take refuge in one of these cities to save his life.

6.verse: Should the distance be too great, the avenger of blood may in the heat of his anger pursue the homicide and overtake him and strike him dead, even though he does not merit death since he had previously borne the slain man no malice.

7.verse: That is why I order you to set apart three cities.

8.verse: "But if the LORD, your God, enlarges your territory, as he swore to your fathers, and gives you all the land he promised your fathers he would give

9.verse: in the event that you carefully observe all these commandments which I enjoin on you today, loving the LORD, your God, and ever walking in his ways: then add three cities to these three.

10.verse: Thus, in the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you as a heritage, innocent blood will not be shed and you will not become guilty of bloodshed.

11.verse: "However, if someone lies in wait for his neighbor out of hatred for him, and rising up against him, strikes him mortally, and then takes refuge in one of these cities,

12.verse: the elders of his own city shall send for him and have him taken from there, and shall hand him over to be slain by the avenger of blood.

13.verse: Do not look on him with pity, but purge from Israel the stain of shedding innocent blood, that you may prosper.

14.verse: "You shall not move your neighbor's landmarks erected by your forefathers in the heritage you receive in the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you to occupy.

15.verse: "One witness alone shall not take the stand against a man in regard to any crime or any offense of which he may be guilty; a judicial fact shall be established only on the testimony of two or three witnesses.

16.verse: "If an unjust witness takes the stand against a man to accuse him of a defection from the law,

17.verse: the two parties in the dispute shall appear before the LORD in the presence of the priests or judges in office at that time;

18.verse: and if after a thorough investigation the judges find that the witness is a false witness and has accused his kinsman falsely,

19.verse: you shall do to him as he planned to do to his kinsman. Thus shall you purge the evil from your midst.

20.verse: The rest, on hearing of it, shall fear, and never again do a thing so evil among you.

21.verse: Do not look on such a man with pity. Life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, and foot for foot!

annotations.1: [2] Set apart three cities: the Israelites were to have at least six cities of refuge, three in the land east of the Jordan and three in the land of Canaan west of the Jordan ( Numbers 35:9-34); but since the three cities east of the Jordan had now been appointed ( Deut 4:41-43), reference is made here only to the three west of the Jordan. The execution of this command is narrated in Joshua 20
annotations.2: [6] The avenger of blood: see note on Numbers 35:12.

1.verse: "Thus, then, shall it be: if you continue to heed the voice of the LORD, your God, and are careful to observe all his commandments which I enjoin on you today, the LORD, your God, will raise you high above all the nations of the earth.

2.verse: When you hearken to the voice of the LORD, your God, all these blessings will come upon you and overwhelm you:

3.verse: "May you be blessed in the city, and blessed in the country!

4.verse: "Blessed be the fruit of your womb, the produce of your soil and the offspring of your livestock, the issue of your herds and the young of your flocks!

5.verse: "Blessed be your grain bin and your kneading bowl!

6.verse: "May you be blessed in your coming in, and blessed in your going out!

7.verse: "The LORD will beat down before you the enemies that rise up against you; though they come out against you from but one direction, they will flee before you in seven.

8.verse: The LORD will affirm his blessing upon you, on your barns and on all your undertakings, blessing you in the land that the LORD, your God, gives you.

9.verse: Provided that you keep the commandments of the LORD, your God, and walk in his ways, he will establish you as a people sacred to himself, as he swore to you;

10.verse: so that, when all the nations of the earth see you bearing the name of the LORD, they will stand in awe of you.

11.verse: The LORD will increase in more than goodly measure the fruit of your womb, the offspring of your livestock, and the produce of your soil, in the land which he swore to your fathers he would give you.

12.verse: The LORD will open up for you his rich treasure house of the heavens, to give your land rain in due season, blessing all your undertakings, so that you will lend to many nations and borrow from none.

13.verse: The LORD will make you the head, not the tail, and you will always mount higher and not decline, as long as you obey the commandments of the LORD, your God, which I order you today to observe carefully;

14.verse: not turning aside to the right or to the left from any of the commandments which I now give you, in order to follow other gods and serve them.

15.verse: "But if you do not hearken to the voice of the LORD, your God, and are not careful to observe all his commandments which I enjoin on you today, all these curses shall come upon you and overwhelm you:

16.verse: "May you be cursed in the city, and cursed in the country!

17.verse: "Cursed be your grain bin and your kneading bowl!

18.verse: "Cursed be the fruit of your womb, the produce of your soil and the offspring of your livestock, the issue of your herds and the young of your flocks!

19.verse: "May you be cursed in your coming in, and cursed in your going out!

20.verse: "The LORD will put a curse on you, defeat and frustration in every enterprise you undertake, until you are speedily destroyed and perish for the evil you have done in forsaking me.

21.verse: The LORD will bring a pestilence upon you that will persist until he has exterminated you from the land you are entering to occupy.

22.verse: The LORD will strike you with wasting and fever, with scorching, fiery drought, with blight and searing wind, that will plague you until you perish.

23.verse: The sky over your heads will be like bronze and the earth under your feet like iron.

24.verse: For rain the LORD will give your land powdery dust, which will come down upon you from the sky until you are destroyed.

25.verse: The LORD will let you be beaten down before your enemies; though you advance against them from one direction, you will flee before them in seven, so that you will become a terrifying example to all the kingdoms of the earth.

26.verse: Your carcasses will become food for all the birds of the air and for the beasts of the field, with no one to frighten them off.

27.verse: The LORD will strike you with Egyptian boils and with tumors, eczema and the itch, until you cannot be cured.

28.verse: And the LORD will strike you with madness, blindness and panic,

29.verse: so that even at midday you will grope like a blind man in the dark, unable to find your way. "You will be oppressed and robbed continually, with no one to come to your aid.

30.verse: Though you betroth a wife, another man will have her. Though you build a house, you will not live in it. Though you plant a vineyard, you will not enjoy its fruits.

31.verse: Your ox will be slaughtered before your eyes, and you will not eat of its flesh. Your ass will be stolen in your presence, but you will not recover it. Your flocks will be given to your enemies, with no one to come to your aid.

32.verse: Your sons and daughters will be given to a foreign nation while you look on and grieve for them in constant helplessness.

33.verse: A people whom you do not know will consume the fruit of your soil and of all your labor, and you will be oppressed and crushed at all times without surcease,

34.verse: until you are driven mad by what your eyes must look upon.

35.verse: The LORD will strike you with malignant boils of which you cannot be cured, on your knees and legs, and from the soles of your feet to the crown of your head.

36.verse: "The LORD will bring you, and your king whom you have set over you, to a nation which you and your fathers have not known, and there you will serve strange gods of wood and stone,

37.verse: and will call forth amazement, reproach and barbed scorn from all the nations to which the LORD will lead you.

38.verse: "Though you spend much seed on your field, you will harvest but little, for the locusts will devour the crop.

39.verse: Though you plant and cultivate vineyards, you will not drink or store up the wine, for the grubs will eat the vines clean.

40.verse: Though you have olive trees throughout your country, you will have no oil for ointment, for your olives will drop off unripe.

41.verse: Though you beget sons and daughters, they will not remain with you, but will go into captivity.

42.verse: Buzzing insects will infest all your trees and the crops of your soil.

43.verse: The alien residing among you will rise higher and higher above you, while you sink lower and lower.

44.verse: He will lend to you, not you to him. He will become the head, you the tail.

45.verse: "All these curses will come upon you, pursuing you and overwhelming you, until you are destroyed, because you would not hearken to the voice of the LORD, your God, nor keep the commandments and statutes he gave you.

46.verse: They will light on you and your descendants as a sign and a wonder for all time.

47.verse: Since you would not serve the LORD, your God, with joy and gratitude for abundance of every kind,

48.verse: therefore in hunger and thirst, in nakedness and utter poverty, you will serve the enemies whom the LORD will send against you. He will put an iron yoke on your neck, until he destroys you.

49.verse: "The LORD will raise up against you a nation from afar, from the end of the earth, that swoops down like an eagle, a nation whose tongue you do not understand,

50.verse: a nation of stern visage, that shows neither respect for the aged nor pity for the young.

51.verse: They will consume the offspring of your livestock and the produce of your soil, until you are destroyed; they will leave you no grain or wine or oil, no issue of your herds or young of your flocks, until they have brought about your ruin.

52.verse: They will besiege you in each of your communities, until the great, unscalable walls you trust in come tumbling down all over your land. They will so besiege you in every community throughout the land which the LORD, your God, has given you,

53.verse: that in the distress of the siege to which your enemy subjects you, you will eat the fruit of your womb, the flesh of your own sons and daughters whom the LORD, your God, has given you.

54.verse: The most refined and fastidious man among you will begrudge his brother and his beloved wife and his surviving children,

55.verse: any share in the flesh of his children that he himself is using for food when nothing else is left him in the straits of the siege to which your enemy will subject you in all your communities.

56.verse: The most refined and delicate woman among you, so delicate and refined that she would not venture to set the sole of her foot on the ground, will begrudge her beloved husband and her son and daughter

57.verse: the afterbirth that issues from her womb and the infant she brings forth when she secretly uses them for food for want of anything else, in the straits of the siege to which your enemy will subject you in your communities.

58.verse: "If you are not careful to observe every word of the law which is written in this book, and to revere the glorious and awesome name of the LORD, your God,

59.verse: he will smite you and your descendants with severe and constant blows, malignant and lasting maladies.

60.verse: He will again afflict you with all the diseases of Egypt which you dread, and they will persist among you.

61.verse: Should there be any kind of sickness or calamity not mentioned in this book of the law, that too the LORD will bring upon you until you are destroyed.

62.verse: Of you who were numerous as the stars in the sky, only a few will be left, because you would not hearken to the voice of the LORD, your God.

63.verse: "Just as the LORD once took delight in making you grow and prosper, so will he now take delight in ruining and destroying you, and you will be plucked out of the land you are now entering to occupy.

verses.1:
Deuteronomy
Introduction
The fifth and last book of the Pentateuch is called Deuteronomy, meaning "second law." In reality, what it contains is not a new law but a partial repetition, completion and explanation of the law proclaimed on Mount Sinai. The historical portions of the book are also a resume of what is related elsewhere in the Pentateuch. The chief characteristic of this book is its vigorous oratorical style. In a series of eloquent discourses Moses presents the theme of covenant renewal in a vital liturgical framework. He exhorts, corrects and threatens his people, appealing to their past glory, their historic mission, and the promise of future triumph. His aim is to enforce among the Israelites the Lord's claim to their obedience, loyalty and love. The events contained in the Book of Deuteronomy took place in the plains of Moab ( Deut 1:5) between the end of the wanderings in the desert ( Deut 1:3) and the crossing of the Jordan River ( Joshua 4:19), a period of no more than forty days. The Book of Deuteronomy, written after the Israelites had for centuries been resident in the Land of Promise, takes the form of a testament of Moses, the great leader and legislator, to his people on the eve of his death. At the time of our Lord's coming, it shared with the Psalms a preeminent religious influence among the Old Testament books. The Savior quoted passages of Deuteronomy in overcoming the threefold temptation of Satan in the desert (Mat 4; Deut 6:13, 16; 8:3; 10:20), and in explaining to the lawyer the first and greatest commandment ( Matthew 22:35-39; Deut 6:4). The book is divided as follows
I. Historical Review and Exhortation ( Deut 1:1- 4:43)
II. God and His Covenant ( Deut 4:44- 11:32)
III. Exposition of the Law ( Deut 12:1-26, 19)
IV. Final Words of Moses ( Deut 27:1- 34:12

1.verse: "Be careful to observe all the commandments I enjoin on you today, that you may live and increase, and may enter in and possess the land which the LORD promised on oath to your fathers.

2.verse: Remember how for forty years now the LORD, your God, has directed all your journeying in the desert, so as to test you by affliction and find out whether or not it was your intention to keep his commandments.

3.verse: He therefore let you be afflicted with hunger, and then fed you with manna, a food unknown to you and your fathers, in order to show you that not by bread alone does man live, but by every word that comes forth from the mouth of the LORD.

4.verse: The clothing did not fall from you in tatters, nor did your feet swell these forty years.

5.verse: So you must realize that the LORD, your God, disciplines you even as a man disciplines his son.

6.verse: "Therefore, keep the commandments of the LORD, your God, by walking in his ways and fearing him.

7.verse: For the LORD, your God, is bringing you into a good country, a land with streams of water, with springs and fountains welling up in the hills and valleys,

8.verse: a land of wheat and barley, of vines and fig trees and pomegranates, of olive trees and of honey,

9.verse: a land where you can eat bread without stint and where you will lack nothing, a land whose stones contain iron and in whose hills you can mine copper.

10.verse: But when you have eaten your fill, you must bless the LORD, your God, for the good country he has given you.

11.verse: Be careful not to forget the LORD, your God, by neglecting his commandments and decrees and statutes which I enjoin on you today:

12.verse: lest, when you have eaten your fill, and have built fine houses and lived in them,

13.verse: and have increased your herds and flocks, your silver and gold, and all your property,

14.verse: you then become haughty of heart and unmindful of the LORD, your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt, that place of slavery;

15.verse: who guided you through the vast and terrible desert with its saraph serpents and scorpions, its parched and waterless ground; who brought forth water for you from the flinty rock

16.verse: and fed you in the desert with manna, a food unknown to your fathers, that he might afflict you and test you, but also make you prosperous in the end.

17.verse: Otherwise, you might say to yourselves, 'It is my own power and the strength of my own hand that has obtained for me this wealth.'

18.verse: Remember then, it is the LORD, your God, who gives you the power to acquire wealth, by fulfilling, as he has now done, the covenant which he swore to your fathers.

19.verse: But if you forget the LORD, your God, and follow other gods, serving and worshiping them, I forewarn you this day that you will perish utterly.

20.verse: Like the nations which the LORD destroys before you, so shall you too perish for not heeding the voice of the LORD, your God.

1.verse: "At the end of every seven-year period you shall have a relaxation of debts,

2.verse: which shall be observed as follows. Every creditor shall relax his claim on what he has loaned his neighbor; he must not press his neighbor, his kinsman, because a relaxation in honor of the LORD has been proclaimed.

3.verse: You may press a foreigner, but you shall relax the claim on your kinsman for what is yours.

4.verse: Nay, more! since the LORD, your God, will bless you abundantly in the land he will give you to occupy as your heritage, there should be no one of you in need.

5.verse: If you but heed the voice of the LORD, your God, and carefully observe all these commandments which I enjoin on you today,

6.verse: you will lend to many nations, and borrow from none; you will rule over many nations, and none will rule over you, since the LORD, your God, will bless you as he promised.

7.verse: If one of your kinsmen in any community is in need in the land which the LORD, your God, is giving you, you shall not harden your heart nor close your hand to him in his need.

8.verse: Instead, you shall open your hand to him and freely lend him enough to meet his need.

9.verse: Be on your guard lest, entertaining the mean thought that the seventh year, the year of relaxation, is near, you grudge help to your needy kinsman and give him nothing; else he will cry to the LORD against you and you will be held guilty.

10.verse: When you give to him, give freely and not with ill will; for the LORD, your God, will bless you for this in all your works and undertakings.

11.verse: The needy will never be lacking in the land; that is why I command you to open your hand to your poor and needy kinsman in your country.

12.verse: "If your kinsman, a Hebrew man or woman, sells himself to you, he is to serve you for six years, but in the seventh year you shall dismiss him from your service, a free man.

13.verse: When you do so, you shall not send him away empty-handed,

14.verse: but shall weight him down with gifts from your flock and threshing floor and wine press, in proportion to the blessing the LORD, your God, has bestowed on you.

15.verse: For remember that you too were once slaves in the land of Egypt, and the LORD, your God, ransomed you. That is why I am giving you this command today.

16.verse: If, however, he tells you that he does not wish to leave you, because he is devoted to you and your household, since he fares well with you,

17.verse: you shall take an awl and thrust it through his ear into the door, and he shall then be your slave forever. Your female slave, also, you shall treat in the same way.

18.verse: You must not be reluctant to let your slave go free, since the service he has given you for six years was worth twice a hired man's salary; then also the LORD, your God, will bless you in everything you do.

19.verse: "You shall consecrate to the LORD, your God, all the male firstlings of your herd and of your flock. You shall not work the firstlings of your cattle, nor shear the firstlings of your flock.

20.verse: Year after year you and your family shall eat them before the LORD, your God, in the place he chooses.

21.verse: If, however, a firstling is lame or blind or has any other serious defect, you shall not sacrifice it to the LORD, your God,

22.verse: but in your own communities you may eat it, the unclean and the clean eating it alike, as you would a gazelle or a deer.

23.verse: Only, you shall not partake of its blood, which must be poured out on the ground like water.
